number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 10, 2012
												Equal parts beautifully awesome and awesomely beautiful.One of my favorite things about this game is that unlike other puzzle-platformer type games, Trine's design philosophy seems to be more along the lines of "give the player a selection of awesome tools with which to solve puzzles and overcome obstacles and then let them figure it out in what ever way they want" as opposed to the more common puzzle-platformer design philosophy of "let's see how needlessly complex we can make each successive puzzle and then playtest the heck out of it until we're sure there's only one needlessly complex way to solve each puzzle." The replay value of this game is much better than games like Portal simply because you can play through it again and again with the mindset of "let's see if I can solve this in some other way..." I think this sums it up nicely: Play time in Trine: 109 hours. Play time in Portal: 18 hours.Oh, and did I mention they went back and added online co-op to this? Loads of fun with a friend or two.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 1, 2012
												Trine is absolutely one of the most appealing games I have ever played! From it's gorgeous visuals, fantastic soundtrack, excellent narration, and fluent mechanics, it's no wonder this game was such a success!Trine focuses on the diversity of it's titular characters, and the level design of it's extremely well built maps. Each character has a unique role in the game, from the Knight, Wizard, and Thief - with each character being compatible with the other in terms of move sets, and combat. The games platforming works exceptionally well, and the puzzles (while not necessarily that difficult), provide enough thought and complexity to some of the maps level design thus creating entertainment and replayability in leaps and bounds!Now, while the game is incredibly fun playing solo, it should definitely be tackled cooperatively. Amusing antics and crazy combinations will put a smile on your face, and keep you coming back repeatedly! However, Trine doesn't boast "online multiplayer", but "local co-op". That being said, it is still an excellent title and definitely deserves a playthrough! In the end, Trine is well worth the asking price in terms of content, replayability, and quality!EDIT:Trine: Enhanced Edition is on the horizon! This update brings much needed online multiplayer, graphical enhancements, and many bug fixes! Kudos to the developers for reviving an old game - and for free no less!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2015
												Trine is a rare gem of a game. Combining platforming with puzzling and setting it in a beautiful fantasy world. It's a 2D platfomer where you can either play with friends in 3 player co-op or alone. You have a choice of 3 fairly unique characters that have their own set of skills that can also be leveled up, more on that later. There is the Pontius the knight who wields a sword and shield, who is probably the best character to use when fighting off the hordes of undead. Then there's Zoya the thief who has a bow and arrow, which can be used to both kill undead or shoot switches and buttons. Finally we have Amadeus the wizard who can conjure up boxes and platform and levitate them, alongside several other objects in the game. This trio of heroes are what you are given in order to solve puzzles and progress through the game. You can also level up these characters as you make your way through the story. Collecting experience orbs which will eventually grant you with a level up upon reaching 50 orbs, which grants you 1 point for use on a skill. Save the points up and you can afford my expensive, more valuable skills. The range from things like the knight's sword to set ablaze to things like Zoya being able to fire ice arrows or the wizard picking up and throwing enemies. Graphically the game looks fantastic. Beautifully detailled backgrounds, which lovingly sets the scene and along with the music that nicely sets the atmosphere.In my opinion it's a lot more fun to play with friends than by yourself. But overall a fantastic game that does so many things right and brings back memories of the classic platforming games of old. Worth a look if you want something co-op  that's enjoyable and somewhat nostalgic. Good Day!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Trine turned out to be rather fun. Probably more fun in co-op mode but the game still works fine in single player.The basic story in Trine is that one night, Zoya the thief, Amadeus the Wizard, and Pontius the knight, touch a magical object known as the trine at the same time, thus disappearing from the Astral Academy. Zoya was there to scavenge for treasures as the Academy had recently been evacuated due to the incoming undead army. Adameus stayed behind to work  on potions, and Pontius had only just arrived, convinced he was supposed to protect the academy. Binded by the trine, the trio work together and adventure through forests, tombs, catacombs, castles, to try and find the artifacts that would break the spell.As a sidescrolling 3D game it has a remarkable attention to detail. The backgrounds are filled with art pieces and the levels are designed rather well, never being repetitive in style or layout. The enemies are repetitive though, aside from the few bosses. The gameplay consists of using each of the characters special abilities to get past blocks in the path, etc.Anyway, I really liked it.9/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 6, 2015
												An excellent game with a wonderful atmosphere and a really relaxing soundtrack.You play three characters, all of them unique and with their own strengths and weaknesses, between which you can switch at will. There's also a small skill-tree to explore: each character has three skills, each of which can be upgraded twice.During your travels through the levels you may find various "secrets" (items). They will be automatically assigned to one of your characters, though you can always switch the inventories around.The levels are pretty short and cleanly divided, so it's easy to ration your play time.For someone looking for a challenge this might be too easy, as I started playing on hardest difficulty right away and don't really think it's all that hard (supposedly there are more enemies and they hit harder, but the puzzles stay the same). But then there's also the hardcore mode, which I have yet to try out.The puzzles are pretty simple.I can recommend this to everyone who enjoys platformers and beautiful sceneries, adults and children (10+?*) alike.* there is no gore or anything and the game might also be okay for children younger than that, but I'd always rather be safe than sorry

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 25, 2015
 Overview "Trine is a side-scrolling action platform and puzzle video game" - is what wiki says. Trine is a throwback to the best old 2D games, we used to have.First of all, I really like this game. It's the perfect combination of graphic and music to make you have a great week night playing an Indie game and enjoying it, solving puzzles and just laugh at how useless the Knight is. Second of all, as I said the music is great, even though it's repetitive, the alternance between the 'enemies are here' soundtrack and the 'I am just counjouring a box' soundtrack, makes it feel really comfortable.In the single player, you have to choose between 3 characters, that are all fused into one body through magic.Steam Achivements and level: There is a total of 33 achivements. Five achivements are for completion: Find all the secrets in every level, Complete the whole game, Complete Astral Academy - the tutorial, Colect all the experience in the game, Earn all the achivements in the game.There are the collecting achivements - where you have to colect all the experience points in all the levels including Astral Academy - the tutorial. And there are the special achivements, such as: complete a level with 25 character deaths, or kill five monsters with a singly physical object, stay underwater for almost 20 seconds and so on.The achivements aren't very hard, especially when you can play co-op, where if one of your team mates does the achivements, it automatically applies to you as well. The hardest one I thinks I earned was to finish the last level with no deaths and to play the entire game on hard difficulty. This achivement it not that hard, you just have to do a speed run through-out the whole levels, but the enemies are so annoying because there are so many, and you have to spend extra hours to complete it.All in all the achivements are 'makeable' and you can do them in less that 20 hours.My favorite achivement is the Winter Secrets - you have to find the Academic, Bony and Crystalline holiday secret gifts.The levels are chapters of a continuous story that gradually unfolds as each level is completed. The levels become increasingly more challenging as the game progresses.There are 14 levels, 15 if you include the Astral Academy.In Trine there are many hazards that are encountered and have to be overcome:Lava - blazing hot liquid lava.Toxic Water - the lethal poisonous water in some streams and lakes.Water - the underwater areas in some streams and lakes(here you can die if you dont have a charm for undefinite water breathing)Traps are dangerous and can inflict serious damage or even death if not negotiated with care:Enemies are often lurking near traps and should be looked out for.The Three Heroes : There is the mage/wizard : The Wizard has certain Abilities that will be useful to the Three Heroes, such as:- conjure certain magical objects into existence with his Conjuration ability;-  to magically move many things with his Levitation ability;In the beginning, you are given the power to conjour a box, into the word, but as the levels go further, so does this ability. The sizes can vary depending on what you counjour. The first upgrade for the mage is that now two boxes can exist in the world at the same time and the second upgrade is that four boxes can exist.As the game goes on, you find different perks and abilities for the characters, and the mage can now conjour planks.The first upgrade for the mage is that now two planks can exist in the world at the same time and the second upgrade is that four planks can exist. While trying to learn the elusive fireball spell, the Wizard has discovered the ability to conjure a triangle-shaped floating platform. This platform can carry weight, providing a stepping stone. The first upgrade is that the thief can attach her grappling hook to the floating platform, and the second upgrade is that the floating platform can be set on fire and will explode.The game has different objects and items, that can either improve health/mana or add extra upgrades to the wizard - such as extra planks or boxes.There is the thief : The Thief has certain Abilities that will be useful to the Three Heroes.The Thief is equiped with a grapple hook rope which she is able to use in many ingenious ways.You are an expert archer, able to kill from a distance, thus the bow ability. First upgrade is that the bow can shoot two arrows at once and the second ability is that now you can shoow three arrows at once.Next is the fire bow ability, where you can break objects and light them, such as torches - this ability really comes in handy when the level is pitch black and there's a pit just near the corner. For this one, the first upgrade is the fire damage that increases and the second upgrade is that you can now make some area damage with the exploding arrows if you miss the target. The final ability is that you can quickly charge your bow(you go faster). The first upgrade and se second are the same - you carge the bow faster and almost instantly.As the game goes on, you can find certain objects to make the thief either grow in health or use an amulet to revive without the checkpoint/level.There is the knight:  The Knight has certain Abilities that will be useful to the Three Heroes - though I think he is pretty useless, the only good thing is that he can fight enemies faster and has a shild to protect you from falling objects. I do think the moves slower than the other two characters, or I just dislike him so much.The Knight has a sword and a shield, and the first upgrade to this ability is that you have a better critical hit. The second upgrade is that you have a flaming sword, which is nice because the whole sword is on fire and it can also be used to ignote torches, just like the thief can.The next ability is the strenght. Here the first upgrade is to pick up objects - but it only works if you have energy so you can 'call the Gods'. The second upgrade is the inhuman speed that can either kill enemies or knock them back. It's a pretty cool lightning effect.The last perk is the hammer. You can use it if your mage is dead and you can't conjour boulders to destroy walls. The first upgrade is to unleash a secondary attack and deal massive damage and the second one is to perform the same attack with massive damage but while jumping from a ledge. Objects:  As I said, in Trine, there are many magical and ordinary Items that can be used throughout the levels.First of all there are the chests. 2/level - they contain special skills or unlocks the abilities for the characters, thus you have chests with artifacts or abillities. Secondly, the experience. Experience points are gained by collecting the special experience vials and also by killing enemies. These experience points count towards upgrading the abilities of the Three Heroes.Next, the inventory items. The majority has either healing powers or mana. Amulet of the Kings, Amulent of Energy Gain and so on. But there are a few that actually helps throughout the game, such as the Wolfgand Music Box - increses the number of boxes the wizard can conjour by two; The Gem of Ressurection - allows the character to ressurect once per level; The Scales of Fish - allows breathing under water - unlimited time and the Victor's Crown - allows the wizard to increse the number of planks by two.Final thoughs:I liked Trine. The storyline gradually unfolded throughout the game by the narrator. You discover new abilities and tend to have a liking over a character(I preffer the Thief) and you cand spend hours playing, because the game is worth it. I recommend it.In the past ages, three powerful artifacts were created, that had been used to balance all of the good and evil in the world - go find them and enjoy.

The game is in 2D which is not a problem and you have to travel from the point left to the right, while climing fighting monsters and solving puzzels.Pros:-Great environement!-Unique Story-Smooth controls-Archer charater well balancedCons:Wizard charater and Breserker (fighter) Charater not balanced at all.I was playing this game with some friend so one took the archer the other the wizard so I took the breserker and my charater is suppose to be the best fighter since it's hes speciality. So in combat your not that useful since there is also the archer shooting arrows behind to aid.Boss Fight: You do not damange the bosses (mini bosses so far) so you just block and jump around and hope to live an other day while the wizard tries to block him with hes cubs and the archer to kill him.Breserker: This charater is pretty much useless and destroy some of the trio coop gameplay because when you play the wizard you do 70% of the work the archer does 29% and the bresker does the last 1% because all you do is try to jump but it fails so you wait to be moved by the wiz, in combat you try to help but they other can handel it and in boss your kinda just here to watch. ---------------------------------------------------------Conclusion-------------------------------------Great game but unbalanced charaters in a trio coop so if you end up with the wrong charater you will be watching the others play.  I recomand to play this with a single friend not two.        75/100

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												Trine is a charming puzzle platformer with some light action elements. The artwork is gorgeous, the  soundtrack is great and the gameplay is fun. The Enchanted Edition is a port of the original game to the Trine 2 engine and the improved graphics still hold up surprisingly well.The game is rather reminiscent of Lost Vikings and puts you in control of three different characters with different abilities. Unlike in Lost Vikings, most of the puzzles in Trine are physics based. Unfortunately they all tend to be on the easy side. Especially late in the game you are given so many tools that pretty much any puzzle becomes trivial.The combat is rather casual too, and overall I found the game quite easy even on hard difficulty. The last two levels are significantly more challenging, though. At least you can switch difficulty on the fly, so this shouldn't be a major issue.Despite these minor faults Trine is a highly enjoyable game that's recommended to anyone who likes platformers.The good:- Beautiful art that still holds up quite well- Fun Lost Vikings inspired gameplay- Interesting fairytale story- Great soundtrackThe bad:- Big difficulty bump for the last two missions. The game is really easy even on hard before those two

content:
Posted: April 2
												This game was an unexpected pleasure. The best way I found to enjoy it is to not ask too much of it, and simply let it be the casual gameplay experience it was meant to be. I bought the game because the gameplay videos showed the characters moving slowly and gracefully, and that chill pacing was with me throughout my playthrough. Here's how it breaks down:The Good - Here is an excellent title if you are looking for some laid-back fun. The game's pacing was just fast enough to keep things interesting, but slow enough to give you the time to take in the visuals and play with the game's 2D physics. The story was present enough to give the game some direction, but was unconcerned with details and complexity just like a picture book (and with the 2D gameplay and rich backgrounds it certainly felt like a picture book sometimes). The character control was pretty tight, not perfect, but close enough that I didn't find myself frustrated trying to jump onto small ledges. All of these elements came together to make for a pleasant few hours. The Bad - My only real complaint is that I wish there was more content (and I am downloading Trine 2 as I write this review so hopefully that will help). I finished the whole thing in about five hours. I had no technical issues. My controller worked perfectly and the game looked excellent without stutter or other problems. The Verdict - This is not a flashy game. It is not tense or super-fast-paced. You will not feel the rush of victory or the crush of defeat, because it never feels like much is at stake. But if you play this game with the understanding that it is a casual experience, and you are okay with something a little simpler, then I think you will find this game a comfortable match.

content:
Posted: April 17
												A friend of mine got me to buy the whole trilogy, so I'll review each of the three games on their respective pages.Visuals: The game is really pretty, I must say. The environments you travel through are beautiful almost the entire time. There are a few spots that look like generic corridors, but they are not very frequent.Music: The music is good, but the tracks are very short, meaning the music quickly becomes repetitive to the point of being annoying. You also can't turn it off completely, only lower its volume significantly, so once the music becomes annoying, you can't escape it.Story: The story is... alright... I guess... Not desperately interesting though. It feels more like an excuse plot than something that was given high priority.Combat: The combat is acceptable, has a nice flow to it, and there are multiple ways to approach it. However, the boss fights aren't particularly interesting. (There are also technically only two bosses. All subsequent ones are copy-pasted versions of them.)Platforming: This is what really brings the game down. The most important part of any platformer is to have good... well... platforming. This game does not. You frequently find yourself struggling against inconsistent collision boxes. The grappling hook helps, but it has restrictions on what angles you can shoot it in, and has a tendency to mess up the physics simulation occasionally.Other points of note: The final level increases the difficulty significantly. It's still manageable, but can easily get frustrating if you haven't yet gotten used to the awkward platforming.In conclusion: The game is acceptable, I guess... But not something I would recommend. The short music loops and frustrating platforming issues are the main things that bring it down. Most aspects of the game are kinda average, but the visuals are great. I can see how others would like the game, but I personally don't.(A quick note about the other games in the series: Trine 2 fixes most of the issues that this first game has, and is actually a pretty good game. Trine 3, on the other hand, has a couple of other issues that bring it down again.)

content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												This review is for the game ''Trine'',a side-scrolling action platform and puzzle video game,developed by the video game company ''Frozenbyte'' and published by Nobilis(wordwide).It was released in July 3,2009 for Microsoft Windows and since then the game has been released for the PlayStation Network,Mac OS X and for Linux as well.Trine uses the Proprietary engine.PlotTrine takes place in a magical but destroyed kingdom.After a brief period of peace,the king died without leaving any heir.So the kingdom descented to anarchy.During this political instability an undead army appears and attacks the kingdom destroying everything that's on its path.After some time three heroes,unkown to each other,reach the Astral Academy,a magical institution,where they touch a magical object,later said to be the Trine,and their souls bind together.After that incident they search for a way to free themselves of that peculiar effect.The trio must eventually undergoe  an adventure searching for three artifacts that once reunited they could be free.Apparently the Trine is the artifact of souls and without it the other two(the artifact of the body and the artifact of the mind) created the undead making them responsible for all the chaos that polutes the kingdom.After finding them they face a last ultimate challenge where they combine the Trine with the two lost artifacts,unbinding their souls forever.The game ends with the storyteller informing us that the kingdom has been cleansed from the undead and the three proclaiming it as its heroes.CharactersYou take control of Zoya,the thief,Amadeus,the wizard,and Pontius,the knight.Each of them has special abilities.Zoya is the stealthy one of the group and uses her bow and arrow,making her an exceptional marksman.Amadeus uses the power of magic,allowing him to conjur objects(planks,cubes,pyramids) helping the team to overcome obstacles and reach remote areas with great ease.Last but not least Pontius uses his sword,shield and sledgehammer with great force,making him the group's main damage dealer.The player is supposed to combine the group's power together in order to accomplish difficult stunts and unlock the group's true prowess.RecapIncredible game,breathtaking graphics,with exceptional yet simple plot.Enjoyed every bit of it and i definetely recommend it.Edit Friday 4 July 2014Trines has been updated with extremely good looking visual customizations and now is called Trine the Enchanted edition.You should try it out,everybody can be a Beta participant thanks to Frozenbyte developers.P.S Support the developers.Frozenbyte thank you for this game.

content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
												Personally I really can't recommend this game enough.The story, the setting, the graphics, the artdesign, the music, the sound effects, the voiceacting (even in german) and the level design are perfectly blended into a package of pure fun and excitement.Because you have three characters for play at once there are nearly always different ways of solving a problem. Sometimes you have to switch rapidly between the charakters to get one particular problem done. Some other time you can choose which way of progress suits you the most.I think this game is one of the best 2D (ok the graphics are 3D so I assume it's one of those modern called "2.5D" game-enignes) platformers you can get today though I must say I haven't played the second part yet and I hope it will be even better than this part of the series.There are demos available of both parts of the gage. Go on, download them, be stunned by the exellence of execution in this title and then buy it. It's worth every penny even more though it's on discount on nearly a regular basis.There is only one thing that annoys me a little and that is the impossibility to look up or down. There are a few spots, even in the earlier levels, where you simply fall to death and there is no glimpse of a warning. I've played games where at least you can move near the edge and the player character gives a sign wether it's possible to jump down a hole or not. Maybe this would be a nice addition to any future parts of the series. And jesus how I hope they'll do any.As there are really fair and nearly too much checkpoints throughout the levels this is only a minor flaw and doesn't diffuse gameplay flow too much but it could have been solved nicer the way I described above ... nonetheless ...... if you are a fan of 2D action platformers with puzzle elements you simply HAVE to buy this game.You most likely won't regret it !!!

content:
Posted: February 25, 2014
												Trine is a game I can't recommend enough.  It's a physics platformer with a rather unique mechanic of 3 playable characters.  They are tied together by magic so you can switch between them at any time and use their abilities to make your way through the levels.  Puzzles are quite varied requiring a number of different strategies, especially if you want to collect all the experience orbs which can be quite difficult to reach.  All of the characters are well-balanced and necessary to proceed through the game.  The game is also very well-written and acted which is a welcome change from most platformers.Where Trine really shines though is the graphics.  The art in this game is absolutely stunning and it's amazing how well it runs even on older hardware.  It also makes use of nVidia PhysX for high quality physics simulation (nVidia hardware not required.)  The world and levels are very well designed and quite engrossing as well.The only thing this game is missing is coop, but that was added for the sequel which is just as awesome.  Play them both!  You won't regret it.

content:
Posted: January 27, 2013
												Trine is a game about three typical fantasy hero archetypes (the mage, the thief, and the knight) on a typical quest through typical locales to get (as typically) three artifacts. Along the way, you'll use typical weapons and fight typical enemies while solving typical puzzles and looking for typical secrets.Despite all this, Trine is fantastic. You play as one hero at a time, swapping on the fly, and they each play differently; the Thief has a grappling hook and a bow, the Knight is an excellent melee fighter and can lift and destroy heavy objects, and the Wizard can create and move platforms, crates, and the like.The game itself is beautiful, mostly thanks to stunning art and level design, and the soundtrack is excellent, fitting the game thematically and doing its part to add an overall sense of exploration. The gameplay is top-notch, although the platforming can be a bit floaty at times.The game is a decent length (6-8 hours or so) and never really overstayed its welcome, and finishes with a fantastic level that's much different from any previous one. Throughout the game, you'll level up your characters and find hidden items that you can equip to any of the three for stat and ability boosts.I really enjoyed my time with Trine and recommend it at almost any price, but I did have one gripe with it: the heroes are vastly varied, but unfortunately that applies to how fun they are, too. The Wizard is by far the least fun to play, although he's probably the most useful; the Knight I had the least amount of fun with, until I got a late-game upgrade that made him feel, at least, powerful; but I almost exclusively used the Thief, whose grappling hook and ranged weapon made her incredibly fun to play and almost made the other characters obsolete for platforming and most combat scenarios.That, however, is only a personal problem and completely subjective. Other people might find the Wizard to be the most fun, given his versatility, or the Knight, since he can throw rocks and smash skeletons to pieces in an instant.I wholeheartedly recommend Trine to anyone who enjoys solid platformers with a tiny bit of puzzling, fantasy themes, or beautiful scenery.Nine out of ten.

content:
Posted: March 9, 2015
												What a beautiful game. If there are any people out there who have read my other reviews with any regularity, you know that I am not a fan of puzzle platformers. With early access and indie development being so accessible, the market is flooded with crappy 2D platformers and just the thought of them puts a sour taste in many peoples mouths.Trine enters the “2 1/2”D realm because the environment and models are all done in gorgeous 3D and it is only movement which is restricted to a flat plane. The gameplay actually surprised me because it focuses a good amount on combat, bringing in a sort of metroidvania feel without the exhaustive and often tedious backtracking. You can freely swap between one of three characters: a knight, thief and wizard. The knight is a go-to for combat while the thief covers mobility and the wizard... well he makes boxes. I found myself almost exclusively using the thief while only briefly swapping to the wizard to spawn in a box or plank. Meanwhile the knight sat around in limbo collecting dust between boss fights. It really felt like the characters were extremely balanced on paper but in practice the thief really is the main character, only needing the wizard to make some new platforms and the knight to smack around anything she can’t keep at bay with her bow.The good parts of Trine are really good, and while I feel that the characters aren’t balanced quite right this doesn’t take away from the writing, animation and overall quality this game brings to the table.

content:
Posted: October 23, 2014
												Just finished Trine in the free-weekend.I wanted to play this game for a while, and I took advantage of this opportunity to finally try it out. I am not disappointed, but I'm not fully pleased either.TL;DR review = Beautiful looking game, impressive degree of immersion for the genre through graphics, sounds and writing. Gameplay mechanics are not terrible, but they are the weakest link in this game. Not a deal breaker though, game is worth a try.TL review:Gameplay: I know quick-time events are not a necessity for side-scrolling platformers, but when you have a rich 3d environment and heavy physics, they become important. Case in point, the grapling hook from the Thief seems often buggy (often goes through stuff you can jump on, breaks with no clear reason, etc), staying on platform edges or jumping on them can be more tricky than it should, and creating platforms with the wizard can prove difficult if there's the slightest denivalation in the terrain (boxes start to roll, etc). Combat is pretty repetitive and non-interesting, you don't have a lot of moves/attacks, and enemies have an attack animation that doesn't really land with the effect.One more thing; this might be an intended mechanic, or because of time and/or development constraints was not implentend: moving/dropping non-attached stuff with your wizard. It kind of feels like moving an object in editing software; physics are mostly there for the move part, but the drop part is just like dropping from a fixed point with no velocity, no matter what.GraphicsThis is where the game shines. It looks gorgeus. There's a heavy accent on colours and detail, a beautiful 3d environment with a fixed side-scrolling 2d camera. The style gives every setting the feeling of magic, especially the outdoor forest parts. It's also not extremely demanding, at least in the original version; I was able to run it with an acceptable framerate on an outdated low-end laptop, and it looked great. Enchanted Edition wasn't all that spec friendly :D. DesignStory - Not bad. It's sort of like a narrative that you knew as a child, a tale of heroes bound together, who overcome obstacles to reach individual goals, but find that their bond changes their perception, and seemingly work together for the greater good.Sounds - The music in this game is great. It fits perfectly with the story/writing, and with the adequate graphics behind it, it's conveying a sense of immersion. The sound effects and voice acting aren't bad either, but it's the music that truly shines.Levels - The levels are not too difficult, ergo this game is not too difficult. You may find it troublesome to get some achievements, but all in all it's pretty balanced, at last until the last level, which seems to jump the volume of difficulty to 150% (from 100% obviously...idk, I had no better analogy...). Again, it's not THAT difficult, it's just that the game progresses really smoothly in difficulty, not really increasing or decreasing by much, and at the last one, BOOM, it's like you switched from normal to hard (this game doesn't have a difficulty option, btw).ConclusionWell...what can I say, I enjoyed it, even though gameplay mechanics kind of frustrated me. I'll put some of that on my rig though, and considering I'm recommending this game, what I found problematic isn't that much of a problem.

Posted: May 7, 2014
												An excellent addition to the Puzzle Platformer category. I've only palyed for about three hours, but I was immediately hooked on the game. The various characters are interesting and there is a strong sense of storytelling through gameplay. I enjoy listening to the dialogue between the characters as I run through the level. What I think is great about this game is that there are so many different ways to solve each problem, I find myself abusing the Wizard's ability to summon boxes to give myself an extra jump by jumping onto the box as it falls. There appear to be some balancing issues with the characters upgrades and items. My Wizard's inventory is chock full of energy related items and my poor Theif has but a poison potion. As I see it there is very little use for the Knight's lift/throw ability because the wizard can move items around more efficiently and as an attack it is much slower and weaker than his sword.Aside from that it's a wonderful game makes you think as you go careening through beautifully done levels trying to search for experience. I would highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys a challenging Puzzle Platformer and well done voiceovers.

Posted: May 3, 2014
												Even on its own, Trine is a visual puzzle-platform delight, containing 15 levels (plus 1 bonus level) for you to journey through. If you remember the old console game "The Lost Vikings", then know that this is a slightly faster-paced version with more emphasis on combat, as well as beautiful backdrops to the various levels.The game has you play as 3 characters (wizard, thief, and knight) fused into one existence; during play, you can freely call in one of the three to handle fights or puzzles, while the other two hover in a mental limbo. Depending on your tastes, you may relish the idea that the game's puzzles are generally flexible, and let a player choose one of many ways to solve a puzzle. You can conjure planks as a wizard to reach a ledge, or simply grapple to the top as a thief. Even combat is up to you, fight head-on as a knight, at range as a thief, or use a wizard to conjure blocks that crush.Though the game has its downsides. The enemies are bland, with only a majority of skeletons and two other generic creatures. After a while, combat with them becomes a chore to check-off inbetween puzzles. The story is nice, but has little involvement with the gameplay, as the plot comes in verbal chunks during 3 sections: the loading screen; the level beginning; and the level end. The game itself is quite linear and straight-forward, with only small branches that lead to secret collectibles, that in turn upgrade the three heroes' abilities.However, note that this game has a Local Co-op option that I did not try.Overall, this game is more like an appetizer instead of a main course; it lets you get used to how the game mechanics work and tells you the backstory of Trine 2, and you could finish this in less than a day. If you strip away the distractions of plot and combat, Trine is purely a quick (though not without some thought) mildly-challenging puzzle game. Still, I heartily recommend this game as it is a brisk body-swapping romp through a scenic fantasy world. If you want this game, get it purely for its pretty puzzles.NOTE: Trine is packaged with Trine 2 in the packages "Trine Complete" and "Frozenbyte Collection" which may make your purchase more worthwhile, particularly during a Steam Sale.

Posted: February 13, 2014
												Played the game on hardest difficulty from start to finish. Interesting little game though the challenges don't get too much more interesting. Figuring out how to get chests and experience bottles seems to be the most puzzling part and I felt I cruised through the rest. The constant respawn at the checkpoints is nice, but takes away from the challenge of playing on hardest difficulty. The last level and the secret level were both slightly more exciting with a up down scroller as opposed to the typical left to right, but I feel it could of been added earlier. The whole (running against the clock) near the end as well also could of been utilizes more as it added intensity to the gameplay.Also, I feel there should of been more boss presence in the game. A couple LARGE minions that could be counted as 'mini bosses' perhaps, but nothing that really bosslike impacted me throughout the game once.I also have Trine 2 and look forward to playing it. I look forward to seeing how coop may differ from regular gameplay and what kind of advantages that would have. I would not rate this in my top games, and I DID get it on a sale for both Trine 1 and 2 on a 3 dollar deal... But I believe trine 1 is worth at least a 5 dollar purchase.Fun but not OVERLY exciting. I played a couple levels at a time and had to put it down.I would rate the game a 6.5/10 and would recommend for a younger audience, or people just wanting to burn casual time. Still fun, but not overly EXCITING.

												Trine brings platforming games to the front page. I feel like I'm going to say a lot of the same as what you'll read in other magazines.Its beautiful... its thoughtfully designed... though I won't say its challenging. Its easy just like a lot of games of our current day. When you have been gaming since the 1980s and things like ghosts and goblins I don't think anything is as challenging.It will keep your attention for some time as there are many different ways to get through the levels. It gives you options which is nice for this day and age. Its like a platformers deus ex when it comes to choice. Though generally you will find that the warrior is less played and that you spent most of your time either as the rogue or the wizard as they are the most playable. I feel like the warrior was just added in there so they could call the game trine.It may sound like I'm bashing the game a little but in the end I enjoyed it a lot. Probably the most through the achievement challenges and trying to beat the last level without taking any damage.If you buy it and you like platforming games you'll love it.

												A pretty fun game if you like puzzles. I consider this game similar to Portal. Since puzzle games are not easy to make, you make the first one short but fun so you can test the waters. I consider Trine a short but fun game (about 6-10 hours of play).

Posted: January 12, 2014
												Trine is a very enjoyable side-scroller with interesting gameplay mechanics and gorgeous 3D-rendered environments. It has a generic fantasy story that pokes fun at itself and the 3 playable characters are well voiced and funny as they interact and clash with one another. The many levels are diverse and dense with hidden pickups/loot and physics puzzles that draw equally on all 3 characters' abilities, which keeps the gameplay dynamic.Maybe I could come up with something bad to say about this game if I really tried, but I can't think of anything off the top of my head. Highly recommended!

Posted: May 1, 2011
												A great game for anyone that enjoys 16-bit era gameplay. If you enjoy classic platformer gameplay with more modern physics puzzles here-and-there, you will love Trine. Replayability is limited, however - as is multiplayer, so keep that in mind before buying. Give the demo a try, and if you enjoy it at least a little, it's definitely worth the asking price. I just hope there's a sequel!

Posted: January 2, 2014
												This game is the reason I have bought a lot of other puzzle/platform games which didn't interest me in the past. Bought it on sale, decided to give it a crack and haven't looked back.Stunning visuals, devious puzzles with an almost perfect learning curve make this game amazing. Essentially the game revolves around having three charactors, Thief, Warrior and Wizard who all have unique abilities. The Thief can shoot a bow, and use a grapple to swing around and over obstacles, the Warrior is your melee charactor, with sword, shield and hammer, which can be used to bash through certain obstacles, and the Wizard who can leveitate objects and create boxes and ramps. As the game progresses, some of the chests you find will equip you with loot that enhance existing abilities, and also allow you to use them in different ways. This is alongside a relatively basic levelling system, which allows you enhance your abilities also.Some of the puzzles will have you using all three charactors to solve.The achievements blend well with the game, and will have you playing each level over over to find all the secrets and experience. Finding some of the secrets will leave you scratching your head, until ultimately leading to the AHA! moment when you finally work out how to get there/find it. 9.5/10 for me and definately worth buying. The fact that it comes on sale for $1 relatively regularly means this game just needs to be your inventory no matter what.

Posted: February 12, 2014
												After having neglected this game for a long time, I decided to give it a try. So, here are my impressions.Visuals: This game is a real feast for the eyes. I find it redundant to describe it in detail, since it's overall beautiful.Gameplay: The control interface is comfortable and is neither too simple, nor needlessly complicated. The interaction of the characters with their envoirment is on a highly satisfying level, be it objects or enemies. What surprised me in a pleasant way are the physics in the game, making the platforming and puzzles a fun and challenging experience. The combat is rather simple, but decently done for this type of game. Sound: No objections, just like a cherry on top of the cake it rounds up an enjoyable game.So far it sounds like this is a perfect game. But, it does have it flaws, mainly the sadistic difficulty of the final level. Be warned, this is one unforgiving level with literally no room for error. The reason why it is signifficantly harder than the rest of the game is that not only it punishes every big mistake with the need to restart the level, and that it is quite fast-paced compared to the other levels. Another point is the replay value. Once you've completed the game, that is all what the story can offer, it has no extra content, only higher difficulty. That hardly means the replay value is zero, on the contrary. Unless you replay it several times in rapid succession, you can always rediscover this games charms and try to complete every challenge it offers.The verdict: 8/10

Posted: March 19, 2015
												Somehow I found this game (and the sequel) in my library. I don't remember buying it or even trading for it. Today I booted it up so I get some cards to sell and I figured I should at least play for an hour or so (the time it takes to get the cards.). After clicking "Start" I was instantly unable to quit the game. The graphics were amazing, the physics were amazing, the story was great. Heck, even the characters themselves were good. It's about a knight, a thief & a wizard being stuck together (Don't ask.) so you have to switch between the three and all of em have unique abilities. (Except the knight, he just kicks♥♥♥♥♥with his sword/hammer). It's mostly a puzzle game but it has some great fighting parts. There are also some RPG elements (leveling up your character & choosing skills etc.). I played it for 4 hours until I finally beat it.It is a great game and you should buy it and play it. Then buy it for your friends so they can play it. Then play together. (still have to try the multiplayer, hit me up if you want to play.) Right now, I'm off to play Trine 2.

Posted: August 22, 2013
												One of the better indie titles out there, unforuntunately limited by somewhat questionable game design.While the levels and puzzles are gloriously thought out and realised, it's all built around how the developers intended the game to be played: with 3 people controlling each of the characters.This is important, because along with this assumption, the developers neglected to include online play, and made it local only. This meant the vast majority of people played it as a singleplayer game.And what happens in singleplayer? You ninja through the levels as the theif, bypassing many of the more challenging and enjoyable puzzles the game has to offer.Glorious graphics and co-operative design, but unless you have two others that are going to be playing with you, in the same room, with controllers (I mean really?), then you aren't really playing it as it should be played.Thankfully this was remedied in the second game.

												What an absolute joy to play and a really beautiful looking game. As far as platformers go this has actually been more fun for me, if of course less challenging, than Super Meat Boy which is one of the best platformers of all time. The colours, sound and voice acting are all so well created and put together that I struggle to find any flaws with the presentation and audio. The story is very simple as you would imagine so if you're looking for some sort of epic tale then this is probably not going to be first on your list. Controls are fluid although you cannot use a controller, something which I believe they fixed in the second edition to this series. I couldn't reccomend this game more to people who enjoy platformers or want to support good indie gaming or hell even people who just like looking at something pretty. Replay value is pretty high as there are tons of secrets and achievements to conquer as well as hard and very hard difficulty modes respectively. Overall a brilliant game and well worth the asking price on Steam.

Posted: December 22, 2013
												Trine is a 2D platformer created by Frozenbyte.BY POWER OR THREE HEROES... In Trine, player controls three different characters. The Wizard, who can create boxes and levitate things in the air. The Thief, who can shoot arrows and use her crabling hook. And The Knight, who's speciality is killing monsters and lifting heavy objects. Using these three different characters in puzzle solving and platforming player must make his way to several different gorgeus looking levels. BEDTIME STORIESGame's story in other hand, is kinda cliche. Three main character are by accident been connected to the magical artefact, Trine. By working together, they must find way to stop Undead army and find artefacts which could undo Trine's spell. Story won't seems like much first, but feels like it was rip off from bedtime storybook and sucks player into himself by it's charm and music.DIFFERENT KINDA PUZZLERTrine mixes in it's gameplay puzzle solving, platforming and hack 'n slash. Especially in puzzle solving game shines. Mixing all three characters player can find several different solutions in puzzles, but was those solved by own way, progressing feels satisfying. Game have couple problems which could be worth to mentioning. First, enemy waves have bad habit to continue even then, when player have had enough, and second, game don't have any kinda online co-op, which is shame, because this game almost sceam for the online co-op. Levels are full of secrets like exp-bottles and special items which give game small RPG-feeling.VERDICT:Trine is a beautiful and personal looking puzzle platformer with it's couple annoying parts and not having online co-op. I suggest everyone who have any kinda interest to puzzle games and/or platform games.      7.9/10

Posted: February 26, 2016
												I seriously LOVE this game. You will, too. Go play it. It's a physics-based puzzle-platformer with combat as well, with collectibles. It seriously has everything. You can alternate at will with three different characters, a knight (good at fighting, has a shileld, can smash things), a thief (ranged weapon, can grapple to things), and a wizard (who can summon boxes, planks and floating platforms). Each level is filled with traps, platforms, undead skeletons summoned around you to attack, and you're constantly switching between characters. Want to kill that far-off archer? Use your thief to shoot it. Surrounded by melee baddies? Use your knight. Need to cross a dangerous pit? Use your wizard to summon things to make a path. There are tons of different ways to play, too. Trying to reach a high up ledge with a collecible on it? You can 1) shoot down the wood planks holding it up (if possible), 2) platform jump some tricky moves, 3) build a tower of blocks or a plank bridge and just walk right over to it, 4) summon something and use it to knock the collectible from the ledge to the ground. There are certain tasks that can only be done with a certain character, or need to be done with a certain character if you haven't upgraded another one sufficiently, but usually there are tons of different ways to brute force a problem.Pros:+Great art. Fantasy setting with lots of giant mushrooms and sparkling fairy plants in woodland settings, creepy dungeons with lava, broken down castles with poisonous goop.+Adjustable difficulty. The default is medium (which is what I played at) and there are sometimes a bunch of baddies swarming on you all at once, but they're usually three weak hits to kill the weak ones, then you start getting better equipped baddies with shield or armor that take more hits. You can play on easy and (I assume) have less baddies or easier to kill ones, or harder if you like a challenge. I'm going to definitely replay on a harder difficulty at some point because this game is truly awesome.+Pretty good music, never setting too serious a tone to fit the style of the game. Baroque fantasy.+MANY ways to solve puzzles, and they're never TOO challenging. Very fun.+Variety of puzzles. Running away from lava, fighting spiders in the dark, low-stress puzzles, complicated platform jumping, etc.+Decent voice acting. Not amazing (except for maybe the thief), but not intrusive or annoying.+XP and leveling. You collect XP through fighting, but also as collectibles. So the more adventurous you are trying to find the hidden ones, the more you level. There's a limited but interesting set of skills to upgrade, making your fighter tougher and making him charge and fling objects at people, and allowing your wizard to summon more objects, making puzzle and platforming easier, and making your thief shoot more arrows, or light things on fire, etc.+Fair checkpoints. Also, if one of your characters dies, you can switch to another. Anytime you want to revive a dead one, just go back to a checkpoint and they return with limited health. This helps A LOT if you really need the wizard for a puzzle but he just got murdered.Cons:-Uh...I'm getting really nitpicky here, because it's just a superbly fun, well-crafted game, but the final boss level has very few checkpoints, but it's the boss so I totally understand.10/10. Will play again. And the sequel.

												Not a bad game, especially if it can be had for cheap.The graphics are good, and (for what it is) the writing is okay-ish. It has a bit of humour, and has personality that many games which cost five times as much would kill for. You can tell a lot of love went into this game.SADLY, it's really janky. The platforming mixed with physics can be really frustrating to play, not because it's difficult, but because it's not very accurate. This can lead to lots of "miscalcuated" jumps, and whatnot.Besides that, there's really not much variety to the game, and the core mechanics of switching between Wizard, Thief and Knight to battle and solve physics puzzles really don't cut it after a couple of hours.I'd be hard pushed to recommend this game at £6.99 unless you have a real itch for a physics-based puzzle/action/platformer. But if it's more than 25% off in a sale, go for it!3/5

Posted: August 8, 2012
												Trine is a good game, I mostly enjoyed it and I think my critisisms are just based on me not being a huge fan of platformers. You control three characters, switching between them at will. The wizard conjures objects to help you move around, the knight is for melee attacks, and the thief can use her bow to swing over gaps and attack from range. The fun part is figuring out how to combine these abilities to progress. At times the physics can be a little fiddly, not doing quite what you were hoping for, but its not a huge problem. Most areas have multiple solutions so the player shouldn't be stuck for long. I found the combat to be a bit tedious, as most enemies respawn about five times before finally staying dead. It feels like unnecessary padding. Level design is colourful and the story and voice acting are decent. I didn't suffer any bugs or crashes. Trine lasts around 6 hours, and there's not much scope for replayability, but the purchase price is cheap so value for money is good.

Posted: December 31, 2011
												Trine, this game has received positive feedback in general, and to be honest, it is well deserved. It is probably the best side scrolling RPG I've ever played and one of the greatest side scrollers ever played. The gameplay itself is a combination of physics/platforming and combat. You switch between one of the three classes to deal with obtacles and progress in the game. The story itself is good, with a pretty intriguing story and cast of characters, the dialogue is good for a couple laughs here and there, making an overall enjoyable experience. With the prices this game has had, there is no excuse not to own this amazing game, its a purchase you won't regret.

Posted: September 16, 2014
												I got Trine Collection which included this game as well as  Trine 2:The Complete Story for $5. What a deal! This game alone is worth more than $5. In a nutshell, Trine is a fantasy-themed platformer with physics-based puzzles.The player controls a knight, a thief, and a wizard on a quest to rid the land of a growing evil after they all become bound to a mysterious artifact called the Trine. Each character has his or her own attacks  and abilities. The knight has a sword and shield, the thief has a bow and a grappling hook, and the wizard can conjure objects and levitate them. It's fun to use the abilities of each character to figure out how to traverse wide spaces, open gates, and navigate to hard-to-reach areas. Because of the physics in the game, you can interact with the environment in all kinds of interesting ways. For example, when I first started playing, I thought the wizard was the weakest of the three characters to play. He seemed like a utility class since he can conjure up boxes to use to activate pressure plates or planks to traverse dangerous gaps. A running joke in the game is that he can't even cast a fireball. But even with no direct offensive capabilities he could, using the objects he conjures, crush enemies or push them off of dangerous ledges.You aren't stuck playing just one of the three characters, but you can hot swap to any one of them during the game when you find that the abilities of one are better suited to your present situation. You can play solo or with one or two friends in local or online co-op mode. I have done both and the game is fun to play either way. It feels very balanced no matter how you play.This game is a really polished product. The graphics are quite beautiful, with use of colors and lighting that really show off the artwork that makes up the environments that you traverse. The voice acting is also quite good and the narrator especially does a good job of unfolding the story as if he is reading a fairy tale. I also give high praise to the music and sounds effects which exhibit the same quality that the rest of the product has. The controls also feel very solid. I have played with a keyboard and mouse or, my preferred, way, with a game controller. I like how the knight, for example, can be running away while aiming his shield behind him. It's also neat how you use mouse gestures for the wizard to conjure up objects of varying sizes.To sum it up, if you haven't tried out this game, you should. I think you'll find a lot to like about it.

Posted: November 24, 2011
												This game is beautiful. It's fun. It manages not to frustrate the hell out of you. Plus the lovely Thief has the voice of Isabela from Dragon Age 2. You can shoot skeletons, smash 'em, chop 'em or just drop something heavy onto them. The puzzles are not ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ like they are in some games and... wheee grappling hoooooooo...Quite frankly, the visuals are stunning. I'm normally not one to focus on graphics but Trine is really excellent. Which is good, because it's not one of the soulless, mass-produced turds that get released so much lately. That could tempt you to think it's just the visuals. but no, as I said - while it depends on the player, I found the balance between combat, puzzles and platforming quite appealing. There are also things to pick up for all the completionists, so you might find yourself replaying Trine if you're that kind of a person. I guess my main gripe with the game could be that it doesn't really have big flaws. It's not frustrating, you might actually consider that one. I don't. The game isn't really particularly hard, except possibly finding all the hidden thingamajigs. While there's not much of variety in opponents, they're not exactly the main focus either and the levels actually show variety. Which is pretty good, as copy-pasting is a pretty nasty sin.Trine hits quite a few nice spots and it calls back to the nostalgia days of Super Mario, just without taking the wrong cues - instead of picking up the ugly graphics and frustration, it takes the spirit of platforming and adds a spin on it. And while it uses physics for its puzzles, it avoids the pitfalls of that fairly well, delivering quite consistent results to what you do. It also gives you freedom to approach a few places in different ways, which is good - but as my memory serves, that resulted in me mostly using the Thief and the Wizard, with the Knight just doing bugger all except freak accidents when he was actually needed.The game is pretty good, if a little short. I'm a bit on the fence whether it's a good thing or not, but then again it does avoid the pitfall of stretching everything too far and lets you have some carefree fun in between things. It's not even particularly rough around the edges, so it's definitely worth checking out.

Posted: February 17, 2015
												Trine!! Such a great idea and also well implemented... what else can you ask for? This is one of those games that are kind of special to me, along with its sequel Trine 2. Athough the game was launched in 2009, the developers updated the game not long ago with a lot of new stuff. I never really paid too much attention to the story of the game, but that's just because the game is so fun that I was always eager to get started. The gameplay mechanics are great, I love how each character does different things and serves a different role within the group. In fact, I'd recommend playing this game with your significant other/housecarl. This is one of those great co-op games, definitely perfect for a couple or maybe even some friends... so long as there are just 3 of you! It is true that the game is not hard at all, with the exception of the last stages,  but even on easy it'll take you some time to find everything in the game and discover all its secrets. I just managed to get all the achievements and it took me about 15 hours, but I'd say the main game would take you about 6 or 7 hours. Definitely more if you replay some of the stages, or if you like to go treasure hunting like me!  Oh, and in case none of your friends have the game but you still want to collaborate with other people while playing, remember that Trine also has an online mode. Besides all this, the game is in a lot of different languages and the dubbing is also very good in all the versions I've heard so far. I'd mention its cons, but I simply don't see any. Don't think about it too much, just choose the knight, the thief or the wizard and find that elusive Trine before it's too late!

Posted: February 14, 2015
												I was very happy from start to finish playing Trine. Trine is a relatively short platformer that uses 3 distinct characters with unique skills to help you progress and collect all the experience bottles throughout each level. You can change characters on the fly just by pressing 1, 2 or 3. The visuals are stunning and I was constantly just looking at the scenery. The sound is equally good, with fantastic music that suited each level. It's worth noting the sound effects were all great and of very high quality. There are several different enemies and "bosses" throughout the game. However, the enemies lack variety and will constantly repeat over and over. I put bosses in quotes because they are actually quite easy. Maybe mini-bosses is a better term. Trine is a very forgiving game (played on the default difficulty). It's easy to pick up and play a level. It never gets very difficult and has a very generous checkpoint/revival system. The story is as good as it can be for a game like this. There's not much too it, but it’s conveyed well to the player through a fantastic narrator. The controls are ok. Sometimes I got frustrated with my character motion and jumping onto ledges. But it is a minor gripe. To fix my framerate stutter +I ran an uncapped fps and left it to vsync to run at 60fps. This caused stuttering every couple of seconds. I fixed this by telling Trine in the options to run at a capped 60fps. Completely smooth after thatFix input lag+Another easy fix. My mouse input lag was pretty bad. Trine has an option to reduce lag. You'll want to put a check mark in that boxPros+Beautifully styled graphics.+Sound design is solid.+Overall platforming is fun.+Game rewards you (with experience) for exploring corners and trying to find the secret chests.+Smooth 60fps+Stable. Never crashed on my Windows 8.1 machine+Great narrator voice acting.+Fun puzzles and having to think how to progress furtherCons+Not much to the story.+At times I fought with the controls+Default difficulty could be a little more challenging+Only a few useful power-ups. A lot of them don't affect the characters much. (This may change when played on a harder difficulty)+Very few unique enemies.8/10 Very goodI would absolutely recommend Trine. The regular price of $14.99 seems a little much. I would not pass this up if it goes on sale. I got the Trine collections for $2.49 during the 2014 Summer Sale.

Posted: July 21, 2015
												First of all, buy this game! I am not really a fan of platformers and puzzle games but I really loved this one. And there are dozens of reasons I did.Gameplay: It feels like an old school platformer with all the running and jumping across the screen, but it gives you something more than that. Unique abilities of the heroes allows you to make your own choices of how you want to cross a gap or how you want to get to some extra experience points. Moreover, you can vary methods of getting rid off your enemies - making it shooting an arrow (thief), waving your sword (knight) or smashing them with a box (wizard). The puzzles player encounter through the game are not hard at all, still hard enough to feel satisfaction of getting through from time to time. Maybe that doesn't sound that fun or new, but believe me this is really entertaining. The only down thing about the gameplay is Boss fights that feel repetitive and rather dumb - hit & jump.Gaphics: The game has unique atmosphere and the art of each level is just beautiful. I found myself feeling really enjoying the picture. Enchanted Edition stands for enhanced graphics edition for the original game and it feels pretty up-to-date.Controls: Strange thing - I tried to play the game using Xbox controller and found mouse and keyboard far better way of playing the game. Still it is pretty much playable using gamepad. I was also happy to find out that there is a local co-op mode in the game which allows you to play the game with your friends using gamepads and mouse & keyboard at one machine.Verdict: This game has a really strong impression on me. I was surprised how I got into it easily and spent first two hours feeling like it was only 15 minutes. I really like spending some time after work playing it - feels relaxing. And after I finish this one there are still Trine 2 and 3 that await me.I recommend it to all of you guys.

												This game is truly a game of art. With wonderful graphics, sound effects, soundtrack, and a trio of characters flourishing with life, Trine really does everything right. The platforming is one of a kind, find your own way through the levels, with every level and area available to be transformed and manipulated to your own play style, with whichever character your prefer the most. Although the story is quite dark, the world is being sucked of its magic and happiness, the developers have really gone out of their way to make this story fantasticly fun, and the comedy and witty banter between characters cuts through the doleful yet beautiful and comedic storyline. If you haven't already gotten Trine, give it a try. I'm looking forward to both the 2nd and 3rd installments.

Posted: March 14, 2014
												A very fun sidescrolling/platformer fantasy game with some RPG elements in that your characters do earn skill points that you get to choose to allot to any of the up to 3 skills per character. There are 3 characters, including a wizard/conjurer, a thief/rogue, and a knight/warrior. Each is designed to be quite different in abilities and playstyle because you will be using all 3, which you can switch between at the push of a button as you play. You make use of the talents of each to progress through the levels, enemies, and puzzles. It is a pretty unique system and is well implemented. The game will probably not take you more than 10 hours to but the visuals/environments look really good and it does a good job of keeping you engaged and wanting to always play just a little longer to get to the next checkpoint. Recommended!

Posted: December 23, 2013
												Trine is a side-scrolling action platform and puzzle video game, developed by Frozenbyte. GameplayThe player controls and switches between three different characters (a thief, a knight, and a wizard) to try to complete levels. There is also a cooperative play feature, whereby multiple players can join in at any time to control different characters simultaneously. Each character has their own health and energy meter. Energy is used for certain weapons and abilities, and is replenished by blue-colored bottles found throughout levels. Health is replenished by collecting heart-shaped containers, which result from destroying certain enemies.This game is basically like a strategic puzzle solving story that just gets funner the more you play it. I bought it for i think .99 USD and for that price and this quality of gaming, i would HIGHLY!! recommend this game to anyone who enjoys this type of game. A solid 8/10

Give the game a try, for the price, you can't go wrong.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Trine was absolutely spectacular. I usually do not enjoy many platformer games, but in this case, I was pleasantly surprised. The visual aspect of the game is just gorgeous. The lighting really does make it feel 'enchanted' (enchanted edition). However, this alone is not what makes this game spectacular. It is the fact that there are so many creative ways in which you can complete puzzles and get about and around in the game that made me stick around. You play as 3 people whose souls are stuck in the Trine. If you play alone, then you have to switch out between the Wizard, the Thief, and the Warrior. Each character has different special abilities, giving you the opporunity to solve the same puzzles in so many different ways. As a gamer, it really makes you feel creative when you solve a difficult puzzle/climb a difficult part of a level in your own unique way. It is all up to you in how you will get around in the game, whether it be using the Thief's grappling hook or the wizard's floating platform (etc). This game is amazing because there are no limits and no standards to how you solve a puzzle/level. It is all up to your imagination :). This is definitely worth playing!

Posted: March 7, 2016
												Quick Summary: Side scrolling platformer with great graphics and some tricky (but not too tricky) puzzle solving and light combat. Great game for casual co-op as well.You play a trio of heroes trapped in a single body by a mysterious magical artifact called the Trine. While your souls are bound, you can be any one of the three characters at any time: Wizard, Thief, or Knight. Your quest is to find out why you’re bound together and how to undo the “curse.” The game is played with keyboard and mouse though other players can drop in using a game controller on the same computer. You progress mostly from left to right in a two dimensional plane with a lot of jumping and scrambling from one level to another. With a press of a button you can instantly switch between the three characters, each with their unique skills useful for fighting (knight) grappling (thief) or conjuring objects to use (wizard). Each of the characters has their own life bar so if they die you need to either make do with the other 2 characters or backtrack until you get to a checkpoint (a glowing sphere). You can backtrack as much as you want in this game, which is useful since there are a lot of collectibles to be found. The collectibles mainly come in the form of experience potions, and when you level up you can upgrade skills unique to each character class (for example increasing the number of objects the wizard can have conjured at any one time).Pros:+Amazing graphics for a little indie game. The environments look 3D despite being a simple side scroller.+Free upgrade to the Enchanted Edition. The upgraded version uses the Trine 2 engine and got a large number of new Steam achievements.+Nice story with good narration. The narrator appears as an announcer in Dota 2 so you may recognize his voice.Cons: Not much really, the game is awesome.This is a great, cheap game that anyone can get into. If you didn’t get it for free sometime in the past you can probably see it in Humble Bundles occasionally. Play with friends and family!

Posted: April 20, 2016
												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This is a Platform fighting game.Interface/Menu/SettingsThere are Subtitles that you are able to Toggle.The game is fully voiced over.You are able to turn the audio voice off.There is a brightness thing but i don't think this is needed unless you want to tune it down.You are able to play this with a xbox controller.Able to toggle "Tooltips"You are able to toggle "FPS cap" and choose your own cap number.You are able to change your keyboard or Xbox controller controls. You are able to make multiple save slots to CONTROL CHANGES.You are able to turn on the xbox controller vibration :D :)You are able to change the mouse and xbox controller sensitivity speed.There is a Master volume.There is a Sound and speech volume.There is a Music Volume.About the game.You play with 3 different characters but only one at at time. You are able to switch from characters at any time you want. Each character has their own power. There is a Mage, Archer and a Warrior. The game has amazing graphics a decent storyline. Game however could be a little bit repetitive, because mostly the thing that you are doing is, Moving and fighting.  The game is from the side. So that means you are only able to move left or right.  From time to time you will see a checkpoint which will also heal and revive dead allies. Sadly the game has collectables. The game has some kind of Perk/level up system.Mage: Is able to create objects and move objects with magical powers, which is really useful to go to some area's that arent possible to reach without it. You can summon wooden planks and squares for an example. You are able to use your magical power to move some of the objects to build bridges with or you can throw them hurt enemies. Some of the collectables are very easy to obtain with this "Summon" ability.Archer: Is able to shoot a grappling hook into wooden objects, so that you are able to swing around and move to new area's or avoid dangerous platforms. You are able to shoot more then 1 arrow if you are going to upgrade the skill or even turn your arrows into fire. This character is usually used to move around fast throughout levels.Warrior:  Is able to use the shield to defend and block the incoming damage. Has a sword that is upgradeable to do more damage. You are able to charge into enemies and push them back with a big knockback and you are also able throw and move objects with your shield. Some area's could be difficult to reach with this guy but he is mainly a fighter character anyway.Game is casual and calming.Has interesting storyline.You are able to play multiplayer.Music is very good.Graphics is fine but some area's could be hurtful.Graphics is colorful.There are collectables :(Other things.Colors COULD hurt your eyes.I HATE COLLECTABLES.-------------------I Give this game a 7/10

Posted: September 7, 2015
												You remember years ago, when you used to sit down for an hour or two and play a videogame? After school and before dinner, kicking off your shoes and curling up with Crash or Ratchet until the TV went off and the food was done? Not a 6 hour binge or a 12 hour marathon session, but just a wind-down and chill out session of zen gaming? Well if you need to be remended then I highly recommend Trine. This gorgeous plateformer delivers level after stunning level of puzzle-platform fun in a relatively short but action packed package. I played through with an xbox360 controller and was pleasantly reminded of the console platformers I grew up on.  All in all a game well worth your time and dollar. Others have fairly reviewed in more detail, see those reviews for pros and cons. I will leave you with nothing more than my heartiest recommendation and wishes of good gaming :)

												More of a puzzle game with light combat aspects that revolves around you cycling between three different playstyles to progress throughout the level. The mechanics are unique though and it was an enjoyable game for a playthrough, try to get it on sale.3/5Fun game but not worth $15 due to it's lacking content. The mechanics are unique but you end up playing mnost of the game on a single character instead of switching between them let they designed it to be. Kinda easy also, casual gameplay.

Posted: October 23, 2016
												This game is very fun and simple. You get to play as three players (in singleplayer) which you get to constantly switch between at any time with no restrictions, making the game somewhat easy. All you have to do is kill monsters, solve puzzles, beat levels, and finish with a challenge in a final tower. This game is set on a 2D platform. In my opinion, the story is too short for the regular price. If you do a medium run (stop usually to collect extra experience and find secrets), then this game will last you about 5-6 hours. Long runs (stop more frequently and stop to look at the backgrounds) 7-8 hours; short runs (speedruns) 2-4 hours. I would recommend buying this game when it is on sale, especially in a collection (Trinelogy or Frozenbyte Collection 2016). If the beautiful backgrounds attracted you (like me) then definetly get this game. Trust me, you won't regret it. In summary, a good game when it is on sale. This game has some of the best level artwork of all the games on Steam.
