												On hell of a fun game.The graphics are lovely,the puzzles are like how the puzzles in HL2 are fluid but some a bit more challenging. Plenty of side scroller action. If you want to play through the story and enjoy the combat this game will not let you down. Id even recommend buying  the Trine bundle which comes with Trine 1 + Trine 2 complete. However I will say the gameplay mechanics are the same between the two with Trine 2 have more color to its graphics and having co-op. If you are a fan of side scrolling action, with a light touch of rpg elements this game will not let you down. It has controller support but I find keyboard + mouse to be much more enjoyable to use.Bottom Line: Worth gtting if you want to play the story of the characters from their beginning.Now with its enhanced edition it comes with the Trine 2 graphics and co-op.

Posted: June 19, 2011
												Trine is a superb game to look at - quite possibly the most graphically lush side-scroller I've yet come across. With twin 4890's onboard in Crossfire, this game pretty much ramps up the cooling fans straight away - it's that demanding with the eye candy turned on.Trine is effectively a thinking man's hack 'n slash, mixed in with a bit of puzzle solving. The three main characters in the game - a wizard, thief and knight become 'fused' together allowing you pick the relevant character for the task at hand. Along the way experience is picked up which you can apply to one of the three characters as you see fit. The only gripe I've yet comes across wih the game is the absurdly large gap between checkpoint saves - which can see you redoing literally several minutes of a stage if all three characters die.Aside from that, I'd highly recommend Trine as an enjoyable, beautiful and quite cerebral game. 8/10.

Posted: August 8, 2012
												Trine is a good game, I mostly enjoyed it and I think my critisisms are just based on me not being a huge fan of platformers. You control three characters, switching between them at will. The wizard conjures objects to help you move around, the knight is for melee attacks, and the thief can use her bow to swing over gaps and attack from range. The fun part is figuring out how to combine these abilities to progress. At times the physics can be a little fiddly, not doing quite what you were hoping for, but its not a huge problem. Most areas have multiple solutions so the player shouldn't be stuck for long. I found the combat to be a bit tedious, as most enemies respawn about five times before finally staying dead. It feels like unnecessary padding. Level design is colourful and the story and voice acting are decent. I didn't suffer any bugs or crashes. Trine lasts around 6 hours, and there's not much scope for replayability, but the purchase price is cheap so value for money is good.

Posted: December 31, 2011
												Trine, this game has received positive feedback in general, and to be honest, it is well deserved. It is probably the best side scrolling RPG I've ever played and one of the greatest side scrollers ever played. The gameplay itself is a combination of physics/platforming and combat. You switch between one of the three classes to deal with obtacles and progress in the game. The story itself is good, with a pretty intriguing story and cast of characters, the dialogue is good for a couple laughs here and there, making an overall enjoyable experience. With the prices this game has had, there is no excuse not to own this amazing game, its a purchase you won't regret.

Posted: April 14
												PROS+ Graphics/VisualsThe graphics in Trine are colorful and enveloped in a vibrant bloom, creating a magical and dream-like ambiance. The beauty is even more apparent when playing at 4K resolution or downsampled from such. + MusicThe music is pleasant and fits nicely with the visual style; also pizzicato strings rule. CONS- Faulty ControlsIronically, controls are wonky considering platforming is a core mechanic of the game. One of my problems was, for example, turning around on a dime and then jumping onto a platform; this often resulted in not grasping onto a ledge and falling, making fast platforming difficult. It was often more practical to give yourself extra space, turn around, wait for a second, and then attempt a jump. If this issue sounds strange, trust me, you would know what I am talking about if you played for yourself. Something else I noticed was that tapping the jump key as oppose to a longer press would cover a shorter distance. As a consequence, if you had to jump multiple platforms in quick succession, you would often fail and have to repeat, making for irksome moments. Finally, the character would at many times fail to grasp onto to a ledge despite clearly being able to do so; once again, leading to frustration. - Basic CombatThere is nothing special about the combat in Trine; it is quite shallow with no outstanding features. The one character, Amadeus, is next to useless for combat because he has no proper attack. You have to summon a cube, levitate it above an enemy, and let it fall crushing him. Attacking like this is fun at first but gets old, and is far too slow especially when dealing with several foes. With Amadeus being incompetent, only the other two characters are practical for fighting.- Underwhelming and Skippable PuzzlesPuzzles were not impressive since none really stood out to me. Making matters worse, are the character abilities which make many portions of the game skippable. A prime example would be conjuring Amadeus' triangle block and then using Zoya's grapple to transverse over an area in a way not intended. Even Amadeus alone is a problem since you can summon several blocks and planks to advance effortlessly. You could avoid upgrading Amadeus fully, but self-imposed limitations are never fun.- Repetitive GameplayTrine's gameplay is repetitious due to the reuse of content throughout the game. Not much changes in regards to combat, platforming, and puzzles, thus being a bit of a bore to play.- Difficulty CurveMost of the playthrough is far too easy, even on hard; however, once reaching the final level, the difficulty suddenly spikes. In this last level, you have to rush intensifying previously mentioned problems leading one to curse out loud. The difficulty curve which stagnates for the most part and then suddenly shoots up hurts this title big time.CONCLUSIONThe visuals and music of Trine are charming but do little for the overall experience. The combination of core mechanics is admittedly interesting but unfortunately dissonant to the extent of fundamentally breaking gameplay. Then there are other issues adding further insult to injury; I can not recommend this game. Ultimately, I give Trine a PAR of 1.IMPORTANT: I use PARS instead of a standard 1-10 scale. For more information, please visit http://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198067268268/images and click on the picture named "Positive Asymmetrical Rating Scale."

content:
Posted: June 10, 2016
												   Ok let me start by saying any criticism aside, that I straight up loved this game and look forward to playing the next 2. However there are some pros and cons to the beautiful Trine: Enchanted Edition. As just mentioned this games design and beauty is what immediately drew me in and is what compelled me to buy the trilogy on steam and give it a run.   Trine is a platformer that uses three main characters who you are able to swap between to complete different tasks in the level. The Mage who can summon different items that become very useful, the Thief who is the archer of the group, & the Warrior who can take on foes face to face.   The flaws in Trine are minimal but almost all have to do with AI. The enemies wander into their own demise quite often, which doesn’t take you out of the game experience quite as much as when the bosses stomp right off the cliff. This usually happens when he is chasing you and your character falls off the cliff as well, but when you swap characters or respawn the boss is still gone which leads to some overly simplistic battles.   The story in Trine is kind of throw away, and serves more as a loading screen filler than anything. For this kind of game though that is actually a pretty good fit & did not leave me wanting more narrative. There is a narrator who explains the heroes plight and what they are about to delve into before each level.   So as you can imagine, the enemies and bosses killing themselves of can make for some pretty easy levels. I flew through the regular levels with relatively no problem, but when you come to the last level prepare to strap yourself in for a doozy. No matter how far you get, unless you reach the one check point at the very top, you will be sent straight back to the beginning over and over. This type of push back on the last level always endears a game to me I think the completion of a game should be a challenge and in that area Trine delivers.    My experience with the first of the Trine trilogy most definitely has me looking forward to the other two, & with the company partnering with GameStop for publishing on a new project, now is a good time to dig into the games if you haven’t already.For more video game news & reviews be sure to follow the blogHttp://www.SublimeGameReviews.wordpress.com & follow on instagram & twitter @SublimeReviews

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
												I personally like new twists on old classics, so I look for influences of good oldies in newer games. So when I was first introduced to “Trine”, I was all like: here are new “The Lost Vikings” (by Blizzard, 1992): three characters, each one with his strength and weaknesses complementing each other and solving little puzzles to complete levels.“Trine” is not, of course a copy of “Vikings”: it is more of an action, the puzzles are a bit easier, characters transform to each other, not being present on screen simultaneously (much like Silmarils’ “Metal Mutant” of 1991). Of course game looks much and much better, the world is designed beautifully,Game’s characters get experience from killing monsters and finding secrets, which can also contain unique items. Level-ups make them stronger in combat and platforming.So if you are into mildly difficult puzzle-platformers with a bit of RPG elements, you should check this one out.

content:
Posted: March 28, 2014
Odlična igra!Sve pohvale za igru i njene kreatore. Stvarno su se potrudili da igra u svakom elemetnu bude zanimljiva i prijatna za igranje.Trine je 2D igra sa zanimljivom pričom koja će Vas naterati da se osećate kao da ste u nekoj bajci, a pomoć celom doživljaju daje i neverovatan glas naratora koji Vas vodi kroz celu ovo avanturu. Na to se nadovezuje predivna grafika sa puno boja i detalja, lepo osmišljeni likovi sa jedinstvenim umećem i na sve to (kao da ovo prethodno nije dovoljno) prijatna i opuštajuća muzika koja Vas prati tokom cele igre i upotpunjuje ceo doživljaj.Sama igra se svodi na to da upravljate sa tri ličnosti i rešavate zadatke koji su pred Vama, pritom skupljajući iskustvo kako bi unapredili vaše ličnosti. U skladu sa zadatim problemom birate koja će ličnost, na osnovu svojih mogućnosti, biti najbolja za rešavanje problema. Kako se igra bude bližila kraju biće Vam potreban zajednički rad dve ili sve tri ličnosti da rešite određeni problem. Naravno ovo je samo ukratko, igra Vam pruža mnogo više.Bilo bi stvarno velika šteta da propustite da probate igru koja je sa ovoliko pažnje i detalja urađenja, koja ne traži zver od računara, gde se na svaki detalj, i onaj najmanji, mislilo.Još jednom, sve pohvale i velika preporuka svima da probaju ovu neverovatnu igru.

content:
Posted: August 5, 2014
												Trine is basically The Lost Vikings as a physics-based puzzle platformer, offering three characters with very different skillsets and many ways you can use them to approach the game's puzzles and challenges. It's not terribly hard unless you play it on the hardest difficulties, mostly due to offering infinite lives and copious checkpoints, but it always feels like a fun adventure and doesn't lack for challenge, even if you'll be able to respawn until you complete it eventually.Plus it's got an amusing sense of humor and a solid artstyle, and with the Enchanted Edition upgrade, online multiplayer for when you want to help (or screw over) your friends through the levels. It's hard to not recommend Trine to anyone who's interested in puzzle platformers at all.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 23, 2014
												Truly one of the most impressive games I've ever played. The art alone is worth buying this, but the game is actually really fun and well done also. As for the art, it's not just the drawings/models/textures, but the animation is pure genius as well. Every moving thing in the game is done with absolute perfection, and even though it's sort of a "2d platformer" as for genre, everything is done in 3D with great precision. Just the way the warrior blocks with his shield clearly has sooo much time and thought put into perfecting the action. And everything else is done with just as much care. I don't have as much detail to say about them, but the music and sound effects are just as great as the visual effects, and clearly just as well-perfected. The physics are absolutely perfect, again done with absolute precision and perfection, with almost real life precision and realism. I'm on I think the 5th level, and there isn't a *ton* of combat, but there's just enough and it's well done like everything else. The game is probably a bit more puzzle-platformer than action(so far.. and I should say there's plenty of platform jumping, swinging, and hand/eye coordination stuff.. you just aren't constantly fighting enemies the entire time too), but the puzzles are great.. not unrealistically impossible, but they require some thought and dexterity and they continue to get more challenging the further you go. In every aspect, this is one of my most satisfying purchases. And by the way, if you try the demo and like the concept, but aren't sure if there's enough to it, you gain more abilities and everything gets SO much cooler as you get further in. The wizard can create more boxes and also platforms(and there's still 4 more ability slots I don't know what they do... that's 4 for EACH character, and I think 5 more for the thief), the warrior gets a charge ability(and 3 or 4 more I don't have yet) and you get various special items for even more abilities, customization, and bonuses.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Trine is basically a platformer with some minor puzzle elements. You will be jumping around on said platforms quite a lot, but instead of having just one character, you have three, which you can change on the fly (unless one or more of them died) and also has his own set of skills. The mage can conjure crates, planks and a floaty triangle thingies, the thief has a grappling hook and a bow and the knight is best suited for combat, but the thief is pretty much the best class, mostly because of her grappling hook, which you will most likely use extensively. It's also great to just circumvent the few "puzzles" you get in the game.Her bow is also a great weapon, even in close combat, unless you are overwhelmed by enemies.And now let's talk about those enemies, shall we?Skeletons. Tons of 'em. Not running around in the levels, no, they're spawning. Again and again. And that is nothing more than annoying and certainly not fun. Sometimes I've felt like in Call of Duty, when you aren't moving forwards and enemies just keep spawning and spawning...You will also encounter bats from time to time, which are also quite annoying, but at least they're not as common as those skeletons...All in all a good and quite nice looking game with some annoyances here and there.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 25, 2014
												Trine is basically a platformer with some minor puzzle elements. You will be jumping around on said platforms quite a lot, but instead of having just one character, you have three, which you can change on the fly (unless one or more of them died) and also has his own set of skills. The mage can conjure crates, planks and a floaty triangle thingies, the thief has a grappling hook and a bow and the knight is best suited for combat, but the thief is pretty much the best class, mostly because of her grappling hook, which you will most likely use extensively. It's also great to just circumvent the few "puzzles" you get in the game.Her bow is also a great weapon, even in close combat, unless you are overwhelmed by enemies.And now let's talk about those enemies, shall we?Skeletons. Tons of 'em. Not running around in the levels, no, they're spawning. Again and again. And that is nothing more than annoying and certainly not fun. Sometimes I've felt like in Call of Duty, when you aren't moving forwards and enemies just keep spawning and spawning...You will also encounter bats from time to time, which are also quite annoying, but at least they're not as common as those skeletons...All in all a good and quite nice looking game with some annoyances here and there.

content:
Posted: August 23, 2014
												Trine is by far one of the coolest games I have ever played. It isn't very often I am able to complete a game but this is one had be up far past my bed time without even realizing it.This game is primarily made of the single player experience but the multiplayer is nothing to put aside as it can be just as fun to play with friends. The game does a great job mixing action with puzzle solving. Each of the three characters have their strengths and weaknesses pointed out pretty much as soon as the game begins. This allows the player(s) to easily decide how they wish to play the game. Each puzzle has the potential to be solve in many different ways so getting stuck is almost a impossible task.The only problem I has with this game is that it was too short. I find all to often that many of the games I greatly enjoyed playing end too quickly. Just playing casually, I was able to complete this game in about 8 hours. This is one of those game where I would have loved to see at least 15 hours of game play.To end the review, I will just say that the grapics are amazing even to this day. Everything about this games look and feel is amazing. I highly recommend giving it a shot.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 18, 2012
												Here's three reasons why Trine is not like other platforming games I've played before:-Characters:I usually could care less about a platforming games character, but in Trine the balance of the three characters and their unique personalities via great voice acting and unique abiliites.-Story:Most platforming games like Mario or Super Meatboy or Shank, etc etc, I couldn't even remotely tell you what the overall story was about, but Trine kept you hooked from the very start of the game and makes you develop a vested interest in how the story moves along-Artwork:most platforming games these days are trying to do a bit better in the artwork department  and the overall artwork presentation of platforming games has progressed very well in the last few years with the advent of indie games, but Trine's artwork is best described in two words:VISUALLY STUNNING!A Lack of online co-op is the only thing holding this back from being a $5 masterpiece.

content:
Posted: June 18, 2011
												Most beautiful puzzle platformer I've ever played. Damn, I love this game. Seriously. I want to hug it and kiss it, it's THAT good. The game is simple. You complete levels by solving the puzzles. And these puzzles are mostly solved using physics. Depending on the puzzle, you choose one of three characters (you can switch between them on the fly) to solve them. Along the way you battle enemies and collect orbs to level up. You can also find chests with items, so it also has an RPG element to it. A shame the game is over too soon, I really did not want it to end. So I had to replay it several times since then, which, of course, I didn't mind at all. Yes, this is a must have ! Bring on Trine 2 !! Woohooo !![Rating: 92/100]

content:
Posted: September 8, 2014
												Quick review:Short Verdict: One of the best games I've ever played! It's a mix of all the genres I love: RPG, puzzle, platformer, exploration, and it also has some fighting. I've loved it so much I beat it twice in a row! I started playing the Original Game (OG), which was amazing, then I moved to Enchanted Edition (EE), which was even better (if you wanna play the game just once, go for EE, although playing both might be worth, since they still feel slightly like different games). I'll definitely play Trine 2 when I have the chance! (Note: I haven't tried playing it online, so I can't comment on that)Pros: Great balanced mix of different game genres Beautiful graphics Awesome BGM Three different interchangeable characters who are likeable and have their unique set of upgradable skills 15+1 long and well-planned distinct levels with their own atmosphere and a lot of secrets to find Collectible equipment to further customize your characters Really addicting, it doesn't get old even if you're replaying a level Nice voice acting, especially the narrator's Even though the game is old, the devs are still responsive at the forums, especially after EE, I guessCons: Zoya, the Thief, is a bit overpowered I wish there was more to the story--I thought it was a bit shallow and I wanted more A bit easy for me, even on hard (haven't tried the OG-exclusive Very Hard Mode though) (OG ONLY!) Moving objects is slower than needed to be (a lot faster on EE) (OG ONLY!) Conjuring objects with the controller is a pain (improved on EE) (OG ONLY!) Bats are really annoying and seem a bit broken (they've been removed from EE)Bought on / for: Humble Store for US$ 0.99. But it's definitely worth the full price they're asking for!

content:
Posted: January 4, 2016
												A big yes! Do buy this game and you will not regret it!While you have to solve the puzzles truly  thinking  about it, you won't be hurried. You will have to be pretty precise, especially with the wizard, but not frustratingly so. Creativity is required, and there are many ways to solve a problem.Beautiful graphics and a fary tale like narration really make this game a little gem.The only problem I found is that, if you are playing with a controller (mine is an Xbox one), the game doesn't tell you how to use the abilities of fire arrows (Y) button, titan force (left stick, tap right stick, tap again when fully charged // LT for the quick burst), and the hammer (Y again).  It really worried me for a minute.But then again, beside that it's truly, absolutely, completely worth it. Can't wait to play the second!

content:
Posted: July 25, 2015
												There are many things that can be said about the, "Trinelogy". For starters, the graphics are pretty good. The puzzles on their own aren't necessarily the hardest thing to get by, however they're still very fun. The characters aren't necessarily the most well balanced, as there is a certain one of the 3 that can be pretty bad *cough the knight cough*.  The narrator fits the tone of the game quite well which also makes it fairly entertaining. This game also has the very elusive Box Wizard! Yes, you heard it here first folks, there is a Box Wizard. He is a professional Boxer in a sense that he can summon boxes! He can also summon some other stuff, but who cares about that when you have freaking boxes?!?!The story of the game is also pretty enjoyable, making it a great game to unwind to. So, if you want to adventure as a Thief, Knight, and a Box Wizard, the Trine series is perfect for you. If you're not sure if you want to get into this game, I'd still give it a go, you never know, you might enjoy crushing your enemies under some boxes.Side note, this game is so awesome that it thanked coffee in the end credits!

content:
Posted: October 31, 2012
												I highly recommend this game to everyone. As everyone knows, I like to get the flaws out in the open early. The story in this game is poor and barebones. The game is also short, as can be done in 3-4 hours. But both of this are somewhat acceptable because it is just a downloadable game that was short for $15 on release. There is a lack of variety in level design and puzzles. Besides the final level, most of the levels feel the same and after a while it might feel somewhat repetitive. If you play in short bursts it remedies this. A huge problem is that even though there are checkpoints in the levels, it will not save your progress if you exit the game. This is a problem because for a casual game, being forced to beat each level is annoying. There are only a few spells per character. Also, the thief is barely used as she is impractical. The wizard should also have an offensive spell. All that being said, it is still a surprise treat of a game.

content:
Posted: November 12, 2016
												Trine is a delightfully charming platformer that is fun to play both by yourself and with others. Both playthroughs I enjoyed.Pros:- Absolutely gorgeous world! The colors are amazing, everything looks crisp, and the whole game looked mystical. - I like the switching through characters. Every character has his or her own abilities, and they are all distinct. Playing as each character is a different experience and way of getting from A to B.- Solid character controlling for the most part. I appreciate any side scrolling game with a good idea on how jumping and moving around should feel. No awkwardness here.- Playing this game made me happy. I don't know how else to explain it.Cons:- Sometimes the game would freeze. That's never fun.- The drawing button for the wizard and the move objects button should be different! Ahh! The only button mapping that bugged me.- The segments at the beginning of the levels are dumb. You stare at a map while you wait for the narrator to finish speaking. Very rarely do narrators in a video game work.- Come to think of it, the voice acting in general was meh.- Was that even a story?- What is the point of mana? The meter would decrease but never enough to make me think "man I wish I had more mana" because there are checkpoints frequently.- I wish it was longer!  One playthrough lasts about 4 hours or so, longer if you want to level all the way up.The downsides for Trine are definitely there, but they weren't significant enough to make me dislike this game or not want to play anymore. Trine is worth it for the stunning visuals and the fun gameplay with friends I'd say. I never played this game thinking eek when is this going to end. I didn't want it to end!There are no jump scares, only pretty things to look at.

content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												Relaxing, easy to get into and very fluently working platform/physics-puzzler. Gorgeous, colorful background/art design (it's a really great looking game). Not very difficult, but there are a few more tricky obstacles. You control one out of three, instantly switchable characters with different abilities to navigate the levels, manipulate it's objects, create your own or fight enemies. These three characters have some personality, but you don't get to know much of their backgrounds and they remain stereotypes mostly:- Charming, lady-lover wizard who conjures boxes, planks and platforms. Kills enemies with physics.- Mysterious, reserved thief who uses a grappling hook to pull and swing herself around. Kills enemies with bow.- Overweight knight and wannabe hero who likes food and drinking. Uses shield to avoid damage. Kills enemies with sword.The story leaves to be desired. There is one, there is a narrator speaking before each level and the characters sometimes comment things too. But it's your generic good vs evil fantasy thing. There is a name-giving "Trine" artifact binding the souls of the three characters together. It sounded interesting first, but it's not worked out further, it's only a tool to give reason why these otherwise very different personalities come together for an adventure, and creates the outline of it.

content:
Posted: May 29, 2015
 Hey folks,So I bought this game recently on sale for 85% off or something, and it was on my Wishlist and I'm glad I got it. I'd've easily paid full price for this. This game is good to play for a few minutes or as long as you want and with the ability to Save the game and pick it off where you left off is a plus.Pros:The graphics are pretty good and the environments are very impressive.The mehchanics in this game are easy to learn.Each level allows for many different ways in which it can be solved using each of the heroes abilities to make it happen, I favour the wizard.The game loads very quickly so that you're ready to play in no time.The abilities available in this game are simple and effective.Cons:There are honestly no Cons I can think of at this time. This could change over time, of course.I also managed to buy Trine 2 when it was on sale around the same time and am already looking forward to playing it. Would certainly recommend this to people who enjoy simple side-scrollers without the pressure to get through an entire level in such a short time.

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
												Oh wow, another physics-based puzzle/platformer you say.  Yeah, there's a million other competent games is this vein but I found Trine to be one of the better one I've played.  Most notably, the graphics are quite nice and each stage feels like it's own thing despite many using the same means of solving puzzles.The story is completely throwaway and the character quips at the start of levels are generic, but neither get in the way of the gameplay.  Combat variety is extremely limited but I didn't have a problem with it because I had more fun just looking around the levels for hidden stuff and solving puzzles than engaging in combat.As a bonus, the devs are updating the game with the Trine 2 engine, so in the near future, you'll be able to play the game with both engines.  The update is free and I have a lot of respect for a dev team to take the time do this for a game that is quite a few years old.  Trine is also ridiculously cheap and on sale all the time.  There's no reason to pass this game up.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 7, 2015
												It's been almost two years since I played the sequel (Trine 2) to this game (Trine).  But, when I saw they had updated Trine to the Trine Enchanted Edition by porting it to the same engine used in Trine 2, I jumped at the chance to buy it.  I'm very pleased.  Just like Trine 2, the graphics, sound, and game play are all excellent.  The amazing thing about my liking this game is that I pretty much hate platforming games.  Yet, this is, indeed, a side-scrolling platformer.  The difference is that Trine (and Trine 2) aren't "twitch" based platformers.  In general, you have plenty of time to examine the area and can consider the platforming aspect to be part of the puzzle solving aspect of the game.  My only serious complaint with the game is that the last level (and the hidden level that unlocks after you finish that last level) is pure, twitchy, time-limited platforming.  It's frustrating.  But, considering that this is just one level (or two, if you count the bonus level) out of 16, I can live with it.  Plus, considering that I got a tad more than 20 hours of really fun gameplay (getting to that 100% Achiement level), I'd say Trine is definitely worth the price.

content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Remember "The Lost Vikings" from 1992?  By the company famous for the massively successful online multiplayer RPG franchise, "Rock 'n Roll Racing"?No?  Where you alive back then?  If not, then you have a temporary excuse.  Before you continue reading this review, go to your nearest second-hand video game retailer and steal either a Super Nintendo or a time machine.  If you stole the Super Nintendo, then also steal a copy of "The Lost Vikings", and play it through to the end.  If you stole a time machine, travel back to about 1984 and beg your parents to get it on a little earlier than scheduled so you can get a copy of "The Lost Vikings" for your eighth birthday.  Now that you know what to do, you have no more excuses.  Go.  When you're done playing through the game, come back.  I'll be waiting.If you were alive in 1992, your only excuse is that you are an ignorant person.  That is not a real excuse, but I forgive you for your ignorance.  You can follow the same steps as the person who was not alive in 1992, but be careful--don't trip over your ignorance, or do something stupid while back in 1986 like betting all your money on the Red Sox.Alright.  Done playing through "The Lost Vikings"?  "Trine" is a lot like that.  Slightly different abilities for your "Vikings", and much better graphics, but for the most part, it's the same idea.  Perhaps what makes it a little worse is that there are typically many glitchy solutions to individual puzzles (most involving either making a bunch of platforms with the wizard, or worm-jumping with the theif's grappling hook).What, never heard of worm-jumping?  Were you alive/competent in 1997?  See the above paragraphs, and replace "The Lost Vikings" with "Worms 2".  You'll thank me.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												First of all I start of by saying, this game felt so great to me I had to get all the achievements and try everything out. I did it, and boy would I do it again. If you want an atmospheric platformer with puzzle elements this is the game for you. Not only because the game is just something you should've played. It's also a bit different than your normal platformer. Because you can switch between 3 different characters while playing with a simple push on the button. A warrior, who is strong and fierce, a mage who can't cast a fireball, and a ninja-like archer. + Character switching feels quick+ The level design is amazing+ The story is alright, but the narrating is done much better+ The various abilities keep the game fun+ Doesn't feel liniair- Terrible controller controls / Magician not playable I definitly recommend getting Trine. Besides it's on sale alot. And in my opinion it's worth it's full price.

												It's been almost two years since I played the sequel (Trine 2) to this game (Trine).  But, when I saw they had updated Trine to the Trine Enchanted Edition by porting it to the same engine used in Trine 2, I jumped at the chance to buy it.  I'm very pleased. Yet, this is, indeed, a side-scrolling platformer.  The difference is that Trine (and Trine 2) aren't "twitch" based platformers.  In general, you have plenty of time to examine the area and can consider the platforming aspect to be part of the puzzle solving aspect of the game.  My only serious complaint with the game is that the last level (and the hidden level that unlocks after you finish that last level) is pure, twitchy, time-limited platforming.  It's frustrating.  But, considering that this is just one level (or two, if you count the bonus level) out of 16, I can live with it.  Plus, considering that I got a tad more than 20 hours of really fun gameplay (getting to that 100% Achiement level), I'd say Trine is definitely worth the price.

Just like Trine 2, the graphics, sound, and game play are all excellent.  The amazing thing about my liking this game is that I pretty much hate platforming games.  Yet, this is, indeed, a side-scrolling platformer.  The difference is that Trine (and Trine 2) aren't "twitch" based platformers.  In general, you have plenty of time to examine the area and can consider the platforming aspect to be part of the puzzle solving aspect of the game.  My only serious complaint with the game is that the last level (and the hidden level that unlocks after you finish that last level) is pure, twitchy, time-limited platforming.  It's frustrating.  But, considering that this is just one level (or two, if you count the bonus level) out of 16, I can live with it.  Plus, considering that I got a tad more than 20 hours of really fun gameplay (getting to that 100% Achiement level), I'd say Trine is definitely worth the price.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: June 22, 2015
												Remember "The Lost Vikings" from 1992?  By the company famous for the massively successful online multiplayer RPG franchise, "Rock 'n Roll Racing"?No?  Where you alive back then?  If not, then you have a temporary excuse.  Before you continue reading this review, go to your nearest second-hand video game retailer and steal either a Super Nintendo or a time machine.  If you stole the Super Nintendo, then also steal a copy of "The Lost Vikings", and play it through to the end.  If you stole a time machine, travel back to about 1984 and beg your parents to get it on a little earlier than scheduled so you can get a copy of "The Lost Vikings" for your eighth birthday.  Now that you know what to do, you have no more excuses.  Go.  When you're done playing through the game, come back.  I'll be waiting.If you were alive in 1992, your only excuse is that you are an ignorant person.  That is not a real excuse, but I forgive you for your ignorance.  You can follow the same steps as the person who was not alive in 1992, but be careful--don't trip over your ignorance, or do something stupid while back in 1986 like betting all your money on the Red Sox.Alright.  Done playing through "The Lost Vikings"?  "Trine" is a lot like that.  Slightly different abilities for your "Vikings", and much better graphics, but for the most part, it's the same idea.  Perhaps what makes it a little worse is that there are typically many glitchy solutions to individual puzzles (most involving either making a bunch of platforms with the wizard, or worm-jumping with the theif's grappling hook).What, never heard of worm-jumping?  Were you alive/competent in 1997?  See the above paragraphs, and replace "The Lost Vikings" with "Worms 2".  You'll thank me.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
												First of all I start of by saying, this game felt so great to me I had to get all the achievements and try everything out. I did it, and boy would I do it again. If you want an atmospheric platformer with puzzle elements this is the game for you. Not only because the game is just something you should've played. It's also a bit different than your normal platformer. Because you can switch between 3 different characters while playing with a simple push on the button. A warrior, who is strong and fierce, a mage who can't cast a fireball, and a ninja-like archer. + Character switching feels quick+ The level design is amazing+ The story is alright, but the narrating is done much better+ The various abilities keep the game fun+ Doesn't feel liniair- Terrible controller controls / Magician not playable I definitly recommend getting Trine. Besides it's on sale alot. And in my opinion it's worth it's full price.

Posted: October 15, 2016
												Bleh. It's not bad or good, it's just bleh. The story and characters are generic, the jumping is floaty, and you can easily beat the first levels in no time at all as the wizard (hence why I have such a low playtime), thus negating the other characters. The game looks beautiful and has a great soundtrack, but that's it. If as much time and heart were put in the actual game as the soundtrack, this game would be stellar.

content:
Posted: May 26, 2015
												This here is my first review, and I can wholeheartedly say that I'm glad my first review is this game. This game is, frankly, amazing. Honestly, I don't even know what makes it so good. It should just be your everyday platformer game. Jump around, try not to fall, etc. But it's not. It's so much more. The story isn't too bad, actually it's pretty good. The characters are all funny and lovable. The puzzles are fun to solve, and there are multiple ways to solve them. You could just try to jump across the gap, for example, or you could have your wizard conjure a bridge to cross. Or, you could have your thief grapple hook over the gap. The art is beautiful, just beautiful.BUY THIS GAME!

												Beautiful game Enjoyed it through and through until the crappy last levelEdit: I have decided to update a few of my reviews and give them a bit more essence  then basically the thumbs up + tiny explaination or the likejust look at the screenshots to see how good looking this game is the movement is good and the pacing also felt goodthe reason that I thought that the last level was crappy is because (SPOILER) it is a timed event with a bit of a luck system to it in that you have to outjump a rising lava flow (or something like that) and obsticals and enemies are in the way while you are trying to climb to not insta die from the lava, however I must have had the worst luck ever because time and again in different parts of the climb mid jump a randomly generated falling debri would hit me straight into the lava or the debri would land and pile up in such a way that it blocked any possible progress upwards or to the next platform that I needed to get on or having my charactor glitch into a platform after being hit by a debri and not being able to move thus dieing to rising lava flow. All in all this level took me like 13 tries to finally beat it while every other level I beat first or second time through

content:
Posted: December 21, 2015
												I'm starting to think physics games are doomed to fail for either not being realistic, or being too realistic. Trine somehow manages to combine both, in the worst way.The good:-Beautiful designs and backgrounds-Decent narrative-The mix of characters sometimes work well and are all utilised in finishing levels-When the physics does work, it's very satisfyingThe bad:-The narrative is often infuriatingly interrupted by things in-game, and then not continued until the next stage-The movement of characters, enemies, and objects is all much much too sloppy and often seems like everything's on ice, and covered in oil, making precision nigh on impossible-The physics doesn't work 90% of the timeThe game is actually impressive in how annoying it is, maybe because it has so potential that it fails to harness.

content:
Posted: April 13, 2013
												This is /one/ of my favourite indie games for three reasons and i'll tell you why: 1. The visuals are stunning, lovingly crafted and still look beautiful three+ years on.2. The main gameplay point, one where you play one of three characters which you can swap between seamlessly makes for some really cool basic puzzling and combat. 3. The story itself is somewhat generic fantasy but that's something that really appeals to me and pulls this off in a manner that is not too sterotypical to the point where it becomes annoying but is just cliched enough that you recognize and enjoy it.A great platformer, the high point being it's stunning visuals and rope-swinging thief character.

content:
Posted: November 9, 2015
												At first I thought "well, despite the cons, I paid only 1.49 for it", but it's not fair and would sound convenient for the makers; even if it was for free I wouldn't recommend this game.The characters are too annoyingly unstable. Meaning, for example, that if the char is on the edge of a platform since few seconds, he/she may fall after a little while without pushing any button; other example is: given a distance between the point where you're at and the ledge where you have to grab on, one time he/she will grab the ledge and another time he/she wouldn't. Making you fall on an acid pit or spikes, of course.The graphis are pretty rich but the surroundings are not clear and defined. You have to put your eyes under continuous stress to keep playing, otherwise you won't distinguish the playing ground from the background.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2015
												Trine is a story-telling puzzle and platformer game that I enjoyed very much in the gameplay and coop aspect. While I want to give this game my whole-hearted recommendation, I had to hesitate because I found that the game failed in the story-telling department. The first thing you notice when you start the game is the stunningly beautiful graphics which help set up this mystical atmosphere that just makes you eager to play the game. Because of that, I also grew a high expectation from the story. Sadly, as you progress through the game you start to realise that the story is almost... non-existent, in addition to a very anti-climatic and disappointing finale. I will say though, that at least the puzzles and platforming provided a decent challenge and that it was overall a pretty fun game.So the question is, is the game worth buying? Yes, but not at the full price. It's definitely something worth trying if you like platforming and/or playing a good coop game with friends.

number of helpful: 0 of 2 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2015
												Interesting puzzles and good atmosphere make for a pleasant experience. I can't say too much about the story since I just couldn't get into it. The 'leveling' seems a bit slapped on and doesn't really add too much since you're effectively railroaded into it anyway; same could be said about the inventory. These things and the occasional focus on fighting things just don't seem to fit very well. Some skellie killing is all well and good, throwing a boss into a puzzle room is much fun, but the times when you're screen locked into fighting 1by1 spawning is weird for this kind of game.As for the co-op... Honestly it's way easier to do yourself. And the level doesn't change with multiple people so it's completely unnecessary to have the other person. If anything you're just slowing each other down. I would not recommend this as a good co-op for those looking for a challenging puzzle game to play together. For just horsing around, sure.Trine is not a bad game, but I wouldn't list it as the most amazing/best platformer of its time. It's interesting, a little different, and could be something to do for a little while.

												This is basically Lost Vikings 4. You have three very different characters that all need to get through a side-scrolling platformer. content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												Playthrough without trying to get all secrets is about 6.5 hours, so it's pretty short. But, the gameplay is extremely solid with very few glitches and it is very unique. Combat can get intense when you're trying to make "combos" by switching between warrior and thief to beat back archers and melee scarytons at the same time, and the actual platforming aspect is pretty good. Strong level variation. The art style and the soundtrack combine to make this game extremely atmospheric as well. Soundtrack is great and the visual/level design variations are well done. 8.5/10. Go support this game

content:
Posted: July 14, 2012
												There are two words to describe Trine and that is visual splendor. There are very few indie games out there that has this much color and graphical fidelity. Trine is extremely pleasing to the eyes and it perfected the fairy tale graphical style. While the graphic is magnificent, the 2D plat-forming gameplay is just average. There are virtually zero depth in puzzles and progression, basically a child can play this game and get to the end without fail. Trine excels in the mega casual plat-forming department, but if you are looking for any form of challenge at all, this is the wrong game to be buying.

content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
												When asked to describe my thoughts about Trine, only one word comes to mind.NOPE!I was shocked, literally shocked when I viewed the review of this game. One after another kept saying it is good.But it's so far from the truth.When one delves deeper into the depths of Trine one might not come back the same as he once was.Trine shares a common trait with certain platformers, for instance you must collect certain items each level to get that perfect score. Yet most levels require several playthroughs before you can finish them 100%, not that it's bad.But when you come to a certain point where you needed to jump slightly instead of running off of it, and that wasn't the first time you forgot it either, comes frustration. And as I was playing things just kept adding up.The story was pure horribleness, the attempt at humour was even worse, the wizard is the most annoying character in the game, once the thief is dead you might as well restart the level seeing as most levels requires her to finish.The items are terrible, I can't remember if I ever found something for the wizard, not that I would care to either but there's a certain principle of things.The enemies are pure moronic, they will either try to kill you with a wall between you and him. Or just casually walk off a cliff trying to get to you. Bats are only there to rid you of your health, a lazy enemy at best.This game is stupid, I don't know why nor would I be able to comprehend anyone that likes this.My joy was killed at the beginning of the game, and the horrors of 2player mode (control-wise) ensured me that I would never be playing this again.Also, why does this game have or even need 2 sequels, I can think of at least several things that could've benefited from all the money and time that went into their creation. Like planting a tree or stepping on my balls so I would've been midly distracted when hearing such news.

Short verdict: a beautiful art style is not enough to make a game good.PROS:+ Beautiful art style+ CoOp (incuding local CoOp on the same screen)CONS:- Primitive, almost non-existent story- Lousy, inconvenient controls- Easy straightforward ''puzzles'', which you can easily bypass with Amadeus (the Wizard) on CoOp.- No actual final boss battle, just a sloppy cutscene after an annoying climbing stage.- Just four (?) types of enemies (3 skeleton warriors and a spider).This game is highly overrated.Overall rating: 6/10

number of helpful: 4 of 15 people (27%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 24, 2015
												It's too bad there's no button for "it depends."Trine has a few things going for it. The visuals are charming - the characters and the background have a distinctive, beautiful fantasy-world feel to them. The controls are tight - you will have a lot of fun with all 3 of your characters, playing them in 3 different ways to jump around the levels and defeat the baddies.The main downsides of this game are two. First of all, it's just not challenging. I'm not sure if this game was trying to be a puzzle platformer but it falls down on both the puzzling and the platforming. In terms of puzzles, nothing really confuses you for more than a few breaths. Exploiting the physics of the game to move around the levels is usually how it's done but gets old after awhile. The story is also lacking. It's entirely non-descript. This may be a non-issue for some, especially given the short length of the game, but along with the lack of challenge this meant it got boring by the end of my four hour playtime.If you're particularly intrigued by the concept of this game or you find a great sale, go for it! It's a fun little romp. If you're looking for a bit more depth, look elsewhere!

number of helpful: 6 of 20 people (30%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 6, 2011
												Starts out easy enough and fairly enjoyable.  The puzzles get slightly harder, but its fairly even through out the levels.  Then all of a sudden at the end, the puzzles get much harder, and there are unreasonable amounts of enemies.  They just spawn, and spawn, and spawn, and you have to wait until they are done before you can complete the puzzle.  Then the last level shoots the difficulty all the way up to completely insane.  I was playing medium difficulty, and after getting killed 6 times after spending 5 minutes climbing, I went down to easy mode, which didn't make much difference.  The last level would make a nun curse out loud.Other than the ridiculous difficulty ramp, the story is bland and tacked on between the levels.  The enemies are all basically the same skeleton, and are plain and boring.  You are always forced to fight them as they will aggressively chase after you, pulling off insane manoeuvres like leaping 40 feet in the air to grab the ledge you are on.Overall, the game was OK but did not live up to the hype.  Worth buying if you like side-scrollers and it is on sale.

number of helpful: 5 of 18 people (28%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 11, 2014
												Remarkably frustrating for such a shallow, simplistic game. Repetitive gameplay, very little challenge unless you go for the extra experience and hidden areas. Oversaturated graphics look pretty cool but can be distracting at times. Nice music. Story is generic and skeletal at best but doesn't waste your time or detract from the gameplay, and the voice acting is pretty good. Occasionally it is difficult to tell the environment apart from the background, and sometimes parts of the level obstruct the camera.Overall it's not bad; I did play it through to the end. Still, it's nothing too special, even from an indie developer. On a numeric scale I'd rate it a 3/5.

number of helpful: 5 of 18 people (28%) found this review helpful3 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: January 12, 2014
												Did I really just write a whole review about what I hated about Trine, copy it to clipboard, and then accidentally lose it copying the lyrics of Supertramp's "The Logical Song" into a review for Chantelise?Yeah. I did.Anyway, this game starts out with the neat idea of a puzzle/adventure game - which seemed to impress a lot of people when it came out - only to stop being creative halfway through and produce a game with the audacity of a day-old gumwad. Stop playing halfway through - I guarantee you did all the enjoyable parts already, the Knight's hammer isn't even that great, and the last level is one of those pseudo-timed lava-slowly-rising dealies. The controls turn out to be too sluggish and most obstacles are better solved with methods that feel like cheating, so the whole experience sort of just falls apart and feels half lazy and half frustratingly vindictive. Sliding off♥♥♥♥♥♥into hazards that were way off screen happens way too often in the late-game.Also the characters are idiotic tropes, the narration is predictable, cheesy, pointless, and even kind of wrong in a couple points ("and then they heard his voice" isn't really accurate if the only things he does is laugh), and the payoff at the end is just so embarassingly bad it should've been replaced with a big "YOU WON" sign. The graphical design is pretty nice in a lot of parts and only confuses you over what's actually something you can step on in a few parts, so that's, uh, positive. A big negative is that a lot of the music sounds like it belongs in a Geico commercial or a bad fantasy parody movie - or one of those off-budget CG movies that try to copy Dreamwork's titles to cash in on grandmas who want to buy their grandchildren a fun DVD but weren't paying enough attention to the ads. Although Netflix is picking up a lot of them now so I guess the irony factor is working out for them.Anyway, if you bought this on Humble Bundle for however close to almost free you wanted to get, fine, whatever, but probably save yourself the hassle and stop after three levels.If you bought it when it came out - thanks to your inflation of its popularity, they made a Trine 2, which I bought before actually playing through this tasteless ♥♥♥♥♥ack. So, thanks for that.

content:
Posted: December 13, 2011
												This game is gorgeous, and also the core gameplay design is highly effective. You can switch the 3 characters at any given time if you are required to progress further in a level. The puzzles are also interesting. But my problem is that they treat you as if you were a kid. Is this game made for children? I don't think so. But when you play it, you feel like a child. And I mean that in a negative way. Nowadays, such platform and puzzle games are usually serious and hard to complete. But this one... it cannot be taken seriously, no way. And it isn't funny either. It is way too easy to complete, and the storytelling is so childish that you wanna scream. It has a hype surrounding it which I cannot tolerate. Get serious people. This game is a kitsch. I'll try Trine 2, who knows... I still have some spark of interest left. Maybe part 2 will be better.

												I do not really have a longwinded review for this game (like I do for many others). At its core:+ The graphics are really good and the levels look nice.+ The music, SFX, and dialog sound pretty good overall.+ The characters are somewhat funny.+ The idea/mechanics of the game are interesting, but...- They are executed poorly, in my opinion. I mean no disrespect to the creators, but it just did not click with me. It was mostly repetitive and stale.Others would presumably disagree.

number of helpful: 13 of 39 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 6, 2013
												Oh god, Trine is one of the most boring and monotonous games I've ever played. It really doesn't get much more trivial than this for a platformer, even Super Mario Bros. has more variety and little unnecessary filler.The AI is dumb and will constantly fall off ledges and jump back up, only to fall off again. Weapons are slow and inaccurate, the wizard's conjuration ability requires such precision that it becomes useless in any combat situation. Also, why can't I jump and fire arrows or use my conjuration spells in the air? Stupid limitations.The premise is interesting, the Trine mechanics are innovative, albeit contrived. The story is lacklustre. The narration during the loading screens is so slow and fragmented that I can't be bothered waiting to hear what's being told.The levels are all too similar in layout and lack inspiration. The puzzle mechanics aren't challenging and are too predictable, they seem to be the only reason for the physics engine to exist in the first place.Co-op is almost unplayable and seemed tacked on "just because" as both players control one of three characters, but only have access to two of the characters at a time, which slows down gameplay considerably. It also doesn't make sense in context with the Trine itself. The option for three player co-op is there but I'm not certain many people would be able to take advantage of this on PC.

number of helpful: 3 of 17 people (18%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 14, 2014
												Mediocre.This game seems to suffer from an identity crisis? What is it? Quoting the manual, "Trine is a great platformer game for the modern era infused with action and puzzle elements"Well, I'm afraid it doesn't do any of these particularly well.The jumping is sloppy, and you never really feel confident in landing in any particular spot. The game's physics are sloppy. Very frequently I found myself trying to "brute force" my way through jumps, especially when landing on platforms which are affected by the mass upon them (such as beams which pivot around their centre).The puzzles are based on the physics engine, and quite often involve using the Wizard to move/create blocks and planks to get somewhere. However, this is often sloppy. It feels more like you're 'guiding' blocks around, careful not to knock down any towers you have built to get anywhere, as the thing you are dragging rotates unpredictably, rather than firmly dragging them around. I suppose it fits thematically, as it is telekenesis, but from a gameplay point of view, the player doesn't feel in control. Furthermore, it usually takes a few tries to create what you want, particularly with the square blocks or triangular floating platforms (which rotate and are very unstable)Combat is plain awful. There are four main enemy types in the game, and they're all skeletons with varying abilities. You'll be seeing them throughout the whole game. What's worse is that they just keep spawning. One can spend several minutes just whacking them, as more keep spawning in, with no indication on how long until they stop spawning. You don't have a very varied move set either. It's either hold up your shield and wait for an opening with the knight, shoot an arrow at them with the theif (who cannot fire in mid-air) or hit them with a heavy object, usually with the wizard (who can't move when creating objects/using telekenesis). Enemy AI is also poor, trying to scramble over ledges, waves of monsters continually walking into a situation where they crush themselves. I admit, I played this on easy, but as far as I'm aware it only changes damage given and taken, rather than gameplay or AI.So, to give some positives, the environments are very detailed, music is fine, dialogue has some witty moments, even if the story is unmemorable.

												Here's the thing: I liked this game, but I couldn't wait to finish it. I enjoyed playing it, but I know I won't ever play it again. The graphics were great, gameplay was fluid, and the three characters you utilize are all diverse enough to give everyone their own style. But for some reason, The only reason I played this game -- and continued playing it to the end -- was to get it off my "not completed" list. I felt no push to find out what happened next, or get all the achievements, or even explore. I got the whole thing done in maybe three or four hours, and I don't imagine myself playing it any more.

content:
Posted: August 31, 2014
												Trine is an action/puzzle platformer with 3 types of heroes, 2 types of bosses and 1 type of level.The graphics are pretty gorgeous, but unfortunately for the gameplay it's not great. There is quite a mess on screen and it's sometimes hard to tell a bonus pickup from an enemy attack.The controls - which should be the most important thing for a platformers - don't allow for enough precision and feel sloppy, which will often trigger misses. Not that it matters because the game is too easy anyway.All the levels feel exactly the same, beyond level 1 there is hardly any new mechanics, from there it's just grinding your way through. The fixed camera placement is annoying. You know objects are there but the camera won't budge or allow you to place objects outside the current field of vision.There are just 2 bosses, they're not epic, just merely a slightly tougher foe, and they come back several times in later levels.Not much variety in enemies either, it's just the same skeletons from the beginning to the end.All in all, this is just like playing the same level 15 times over again, with a different backdrop.I can appreciate some may be drawn by the medieval fantasy storytelling or by the luxurious backdrops. The graphics got overhauled recently with the enchanted edition and it's quite superb. One can wish the gameplay had got improved instead!

Posted: June 7, 2014
												 Trine is a 2-d platform game with some puzzle elements. The key mechanic is that you can switch between three characters which have different abilities. A lot of the puzzles require swinging, putting weights on seesaws, pushing objects, moving objects with telekenesis, cutting ropes with arrows, etc. Each puzzle can be solved in a variety of different ways. Some puzzles can be solved with all three characters, so there is some replayability to try to go back and retry a puzzle with a different character. In general the puzzles were not very hard, but some of them are very creative and fun. Combat was a little dull since there are only two kinds of regular enemies and two kinds of boss. I got this game for a very good price and it was well worth it. It is a nice diversion, fun enough to hold your attention, not so difficult that you get frustrated. I would not pay more than five bucks for it.

Posted: July 13, 2013
												Sidescrolling storytelling at its perfection. Trine is an amazing experience with fantastic worlds to explore and many puzzles to be solved. Seamless and fluid combat has you switching instantly between 3 characters, each with their own powers and skills. Fun gameplay and humorous narration push you ever further into this amazing game.

Posted: April 21, 2014
												I bought this when it was on sale for about a dollar so I didn't expect much of it. Instead, what I got was one heck of a puzzle platformer that's simply drop-dead gorgeous. The game itself is simple enough for anyone to pick-up but the platforming and puzzles later on can be very challenging but the feeling of satisfaction you get from finishing those puzzle-platforming sections is just bliss.The way the game is presented is very much like a story-book with the narrator, the cutscenes and those amazing setpieces. You can seriously take a screenshot of any section of this game and it'd look like a painting worth being framed and hung on someone's lounge room!In single player, you can play as one character, either as the mage, the thief or the knight; each with their own strengths and weaknesses and you are allowed to switch as whichever character you want in order to get through a particular puzzle or platforming section. For example, the mage can conjure boxes and platforms to help you with puzzles and getting to places but is pretty useless when it comes to battle while the knight can lift heavy objects and is the main fighting force when it comes to battles. This interesting mechanic has been implemented extremely well within each level as you will be encouraged to play as all of the different classes in order to get through it and that makes for an already enjoyable game all the more enjoyable!All in all, Trine is an amazing-looking game with fantastic gameplay to boot and if it ever goes on sale again, don't hesitate and dive right in!

												Trine is a fairytale game; it's beautiful, it has good and evil characters, and involves a fair amount of magic. Posted: June 22, 2014
												I bought this on a whim a while back and it quickly became one of my favourites.  I can't point out something I don't like about Trine.  The music is fantastic and fits perfectly with every level, the graphics are clean and look great, the physics and combat are smooth, and the environments are stunning.  The three playable characters make up a rather usual tank/rogue/mage adventuring party and, among the hordes of similar parties in other games, still manage to be memorable and entertaining.If you're a fan of fantasy games and platformers, I can't recommend Trine enough.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												Having recently completed the story for this game, I think it's safe to say that I can't wait to start the second one. Trine brings you a combination of puzzle,platforming and minor leveling up elements. You cycle between 3 characters, each with different abilities to help you progress through the various puzzles and enemies you'll face. The scenary is beautiful, the physics are percise. The story is a little basic but none the less immersive. Extra elements such as leveling skills, finding items and secrets and rerunning the game on higher difficult settings does not just limit trine to a single playthrough. It helps to add longevity to a game that, in reality, will take you under 6 hours to complete (but when I say complete, I do not me fully!) 8/10

Posted: January 8, 2011
												Your typical side-scroller with a few additions thrown in to mix things up. In Trine, you may control one of three characters (switching between them in single player or playing as all 3 on local coop). Using each character's unique abilities, you must triumph over the undead and reclaim your lost kingdom. Despite it being an old fashioned side scroller with very few twists, its major attraction (at least in my personal opinion) is its soundtrack. A game is great, don't get me wrong. But the cherry on top is listening to the beautiful melodies of the orchestra serenading you as you make your way to the end of every level. If side-scrollers aren't your thing, then at least take a listen at the soundtrack. I assure you, you won't regret it.Grade: B+

Posted: July 28, 2014
												This game is simple,fun and relaxing.The graphics are great to look at and sometimes you will end up just admiring the level before you move on.The fighting mechanics are simple,you can attack and you can block.At some points it will get more challenging but I can't say that the game is hard because of the foes you will be faced with.The boss battles are well designed and the soundtrack is amazing.Trine is a unique game because you have so many ways of clearing a level.You can be a Mage that manipulates and creates objects.You can be a Thief,agile and fast with a bow.Or you can be a Warrior,strong and bulky.Overall I enjoyed the game,it's a game that you can play if you want to relax and have a good time.The storyline is satisfying and the level design and soundtrack alone can make you want to play the game at least for a few minutes.

Posted: October 13, 2013
												I decided I will start recommending games that are good for language learning. This game has separate selection for audio language and text language so it's excellent - you can set one of them in the language you're learning to get some exposure while still understanding what's happening. But even if you won't understand everything you won't lose much, story is not the main focus here and controls are intuitive. Plus, it's a fun game.

												Trine is just a flat out excellent game. 												A beatiful game with scenes that look like it came right out of storybook fantasy.  Each character perfectly fits a purpose and although I haven't tried cooperative play with this I'm sure it would be just as great.The finale though brings back memories of old side scrolling games where the big boss presents a sudden spike in the difficulty curve.  While you've been breezing along level after level, you suddenly come up to a point where the game tells you "Where do you think you're going?"  You'll get it done after a couple of tries though.Completed in 9.1 hours.

												Trine is a simple platformer that has beautiful graphics and a wonderful soundtrack. The premise involves utilising all three characters, whose souls have been connected, to solve the puzzles and kill enemies to advance through the levels to rid the kingdom of evil. There are experience bottles and items along the way that will help you become more skilled and powerful. My only concern was that the ending was sort of a letdown since there was no "final boss."I got this in the Humble Indie Bundle and just Trine was well worth the price I paid for the whole pack.

												This is a 2D platformer with puzzles designed to make use of the skills of its 3 main Heroes. It is best played as a 3 player co op game, but only supports local co op. This game can be played solo, and most of the levels have multiple ways of getting through. The level design, art and music are the games strongest points. However with the real low price tag (especially during sales), its a must have, unless you really hate platformeers. There are some balance issues with the heroes, and the controls aren't as tight as they should be, but i'm hoping they fixed that with the second one. If you still aren't sure of whether or not to pick this up, try the demo.

Posted: July 12, 2012
												Platformers? Check. Physics Puzzles? Check. Lost Vikings Flashbacks? YES!Trine is a beautiful-looking and beautifully scored game from the Finnish Frostbyte. Three generic (or are they?) classes end up touching a magical artifact known as the Trine, which binds their souls together. With clever switching of class in between finely crafted stages, each gets their chance to shine, whether it is the archery & tethering of the Thief, strength and shield-wielding of the Knight, or the conjured platforms of the Wizard. No fireballs here, but clever use of each class makes it an entertaining journey. Look into multiplayer as well! Definitely worth your time!

Posted: November 26, 2010
												Imagine if Dungeons & Dragons, Portal, Super Mario Brothers 3, and Donkey Kong Country all got thrown into a blender and set to an epic orchesta score written by Harry Gregson Williams and the result would be Trine.  This is a great physics platformer with amazing detail and very fluint controls.  The story is on the level of depth as Mario (i.e. princess captured, go save) but you'll hear no complaint out of me.  Only legitimate complaint I have is the low variety of enemies but each of the 15 levels has it's own theme, background, atmosphere, and well written musical score to complete the mood of each realm you explore so you hardly notice.  The music really is so great that I have the soundtrack on my MP3 player, no joke.  The actions flow seemlessly, weapon upgrades acutally progress at the same rate as the difficulty curve, and you'll keep coming back so you can find everything.  This is the best $20 you'll spend on a game this year, promise.

Posted: March 7, 2014
												Do I recommend this game? Psshhh no.... Ok. That was hard to say. Of course I recommend this game. I am not one to play platform style games... However I do love a good puzzle. This game provides not only great quick-thinking puzzles but also is the best platformer I have ever played. Yes, it is quite short time wise but who says you cant play through again on higher difficulty. If your'e not into that kind of thing... Get Trine 2. I have yet to try the second one but seeing at how impressive the first is... Trine 2 will be on my wish list. Trine is/was more than worth the 0.99$ I spent on it. It provided much more entertainment than I ever expected. It frustrated me at times but that was because I was trying to play quickly. Though this game isn't new by any means you can not really tell how old it is while playing. To be completely honest, it felt like I was playing a much more modern game. The graphics in this game aren't phenomenal but the atmosphere is. (The graphics are amazing DO NOT get me wrong). So all that said... I certainly recommend this game. I couldnt recommend it more.(BTW All you haters that choose Not To Recommend... Please do it for more of a legitimate reason than the fact that you can't get past a level)**Kudos to Frozenbyte for this outstanding game**

Posted: April 28, 2014
												I bought this game for 4€ due to a steam coupon and it was totally worth it. It's a nice platforming where you can controll 3 different "heroes" with different abilities. What I really liked about this game was that you can solve the different puzzles on different ways according to your playstyle (mage,rogue or warrior) especially when you progress in the game and achieve more abilities.Although I liked this game, I thought it was way to easy. I played it the first time on "medium" and did it all on the first try (except the last level where I needed like 3 trys) and you can't really die due to the checkpoint system. Even on the difficulty "Very Hard" it was still very easy in my opinion but this might be due to my full-leveled heroes. The game has various achievements like exploring (finding all experience bottles in the levels) and "fun" achievements like jumping on 5 different skeletons; a good mix in my opinion.Finally, you can beat this game in like 7-8 hours when you play it the first time and like to explore the levels to find the experience flasks which are very nicely hidden and it's fun to explore the levels.

Posted: December 29, 2013
												A neat platformer. Story and characters are basic but serviceable. For the most part, the obstacles are not so large as to demand very strict usage of abilities and so you can solve them in multiple ways, which is great! The grappling hook mechanic is a lot of fun. Combat isn't immensely fleshed out but I prefer it this way, because it keeps the emphasis on the puzzle aspect and mostly makes the enemies a bit of added pressure to move around and amusing asides to watch as they suicide on level geometry.

Posted: January 5, 2014
												Beautiful little game. Had me fully engaged and struck that nice balance of being challenging enough to make you feel smart but not frustratingly difficult. It was fine single player and from what I played the local multiplayer was good too, if you get along with your co-op buddy. The combat is decent, but the heart of the game is in its platforming. I found myself playing the theif more than the other two because she could both fight and platform competently. The wizard cannot fight well, and the knight cannot platform easily without help from the wizard. While this is no good in singleplayer, it makes co op more rewarding. The game isn't particularly long, but troves of secrets and goodies plus extra challenge levels make it worth your while. Decent enough story, but like I said, this is a platformer first and foremost. Can't wait to play the second one.

On top of that, playing co-op with a friend is incredibly fun, and I'd suggest dedicating one whole runthrough to that alone. The levels have a lot to explore, to the point where I was going mad trying to find every nook and cranny. I only feel bad for using the wizard to conjure boxes for a lot of parts.. kind of a shame that it's possible to break intended solutions with boxes and more boxes; but that would be my only complaint. Posted: April 22, 2014
												Trine is a great coop game. I was able to get a few non-gamers to play it due to the ability to assist your fellow player through any obstacle. It takes a little longer, but it adds a bit of challenge trying to figure out how to lead someone with very little gaming coordination through the levels. Even as a purely single player game, it is excellent.  You get a bit of that nostalgic feeling that comes with side scrolling action, but the depth of the game mechanics pushes it beyond past generations of 2d action games. I bought a package containing this and the sequel and I am super-excited to play the next one!!! BUY IT!

Posted: March 14, 2014
												If you're anything like me in RPG games and can't choose between playing a thief, a wizard, or a fighter; then you'll enjoy this game. I just got this game on super sale ($0.99 alone or $5.24 for four different games!) Even if it weren't that great, if it entertains me for more than an hour, I would have called it a good deal; but it DOES entertain as if I had spent ten times the amount I paid. Besides just being PURTY to look at, it's unique gameplay is fresh and fun. You bounce around between the three classes to solve the puzzle like level, while also hacking and slashing the baddies. It's like a light version of an ARPG and puzzle solving game in one. If you get this on sale, it's very much worth the buy.
