Posted: January 15, 2014
												Trine is a side scrolling platform game in which you play three protaganists a wizard, a thief and a soldier, whose souls have somehow been gathered together by the Trine. To complete game you need to complete the levels, collecting experience to gain better weapons or skills is of use you do this be collecting bottles that are laying around or hidden, or by killing monsters and collecting the experience. Also lying around are energy bottles to top up your energy which the wizard seems to use a great deal more than the other characters (at least in the levels I have played any how.)The idea pf three souls together  has the benefit that you can swap at anytime between the different characters if one character has a skill to solve that the others do not. This makes it interesting as you move between them to complete the different levels. So soon learn which character is best for the upcoming task. For me the Graphics make it stand out, the environment is beautifully drawn which makes it a real pleasure to play. There is a great deal of jumping about and I sometimes find it hard to control using the keyboard; especially the thief when she is trying to get onto a platform from the grappling rope. I think a game controller would  make it a bit easier, I am going to try this to see if is indeed true. The default movement controls are the standard WASD controls perhaps if you wish to use the keyboard to play, redefining the keys could also improve things.Another positive aspect of the game is the narration which makes you feel you are creating the book as you go along. The music also adds to the atmosphere quite well.During the hours I've played I've lost a character because they ran out of health many, many times. If you feel you wish to start over. You can choose from the menu to either start from the last checkpoint or restart the level. Restarting from the last checkpoint doesn't reset the monsters and puzzles that you've completed whilst restarting the level does reset the puzzles and monsters. However collected experience is retained by you upon the restart so during the restart you will only see the experience you haven't collected, so far.I thoroughly recommend Trine and I will continue with Trine2 once I've completed Trine.

Posted: July 13, 2015
												Trine is a fantasy puzzle platformer where you play 3 characters (The wizard, the knight, and the thief) stuck in the same body (thus allowing you to switch between characters).  You can play single-player or online or local co-op for up to 3 players.I stopped paying attention to the story pretty quickly (which is offered in the form of narration in between levels and the occasional cutscene of still art) but I enjoyed the gameplay very much.  At times it can be a little difficult to quickly switch between characters to do tasks while fighting enemies, but it's pretty manageable.  The only spot that gave me any real trouble was the final level where you have to reach the top as rising lava fills the floor beneath you.Another thing I really liked was the save system.  You can save just about anywhere at just about any time which is perfect for quick play sessions.  I'm really looking forward to playing the sequels.

Posted: November 24, 2011
												Addictive platform/puzzle game. The bodies of a wizard, a knight and a thief get fused together and you have to control them, switching between one of the three at will, on quest to save the kingdom and separate themselves. The wizzard can move objects telekenetically and conjure platforms, boxes etc, the thief has a bow and grappling hook you can swing from and the knight is a hand-to-hand fighter. You need to collect experience vials as you go which are hidden in hard to reach places which require some thought and a combination of the character's skills to get to. Trine 2 seems to be more of the same.

Posted: January 15, 2014
												Trine is a side scrolling platform game in which you play three protaganists a wizard, a thief and a soldier, whose souls have somehow been gathered together by the Trine. To complete game you need to complete the levels, collecting experience to gain better weapons or skills is of use you do this be collecting bottles that are laying around or hidden, or by killing monsters and collecting the experience. Also lying around are energy bottles to top up your energy which the wizard seems to use a great deal more than the other characters (at least in the levels I have played any how.)The idea pf three souls together  has the benefit that you can swap at anytime between the different characters if one character has a skill to solve that the others do not. This makes it interesting as you move between them to complete the different levels. So soon learn which character is best for the upcoming task. For me the Graphics make it stand out, the environment is beautifully drawn which makes it a real pleasure to play. There is a great deal of jumping about and I sometimes find it hard to control using the keyboard; especially the thief when she is trying to get onto a platform from the grappling rope. I think a game controller would  make it a bit easier, I am going to try this to see if is indeed true. The default movement controls are the standard WASD controls perhaps if you wish to use the keyboard to play, redefining the keys could also improve things.Another positive aspect of the game is the narration which makes you feel you are creating the book as you go along. The music also adds to the atmosphere quite well.During the hours I've played I've lost a character because they ran out of health many, many times. If you feel you wish to start over. You can choose from the menu to either start from the last checkpoint or restart the level. Restarting from the last checkpoint doesn't reset the monsters and puzzles that you've completed whilst restarting the level does reset the puzzles and monsters. However collected experience is retained by you upon the restart so during the restart you will only see the experience you haven't collected, so far.I thoroughly recommend Trine and I will continue with Trine2 once I've completed Trine.

Posted: January 19, 2014
												What to say about Trine...genius? perfect? Maybe. Trine is platforming at it's greatest. There is no one specific way to solve the game's puzzles. Also, the entire thing can be played 3 player co-op either online, via LAN or on the same PC provided you have some spare controllers or an extra mouse and keyboard. That's what makes Trine and Trine 2 absolute gold; working together with your friends (or hindering them) is absolutely a blast.Just go play the series with a friend or two and you'll see what I mean.

												Awesome game that takes you by surprise. For a side-scrolling-platforming-puzzler it is quite the game, giving you a new sense of adventure with its epic graphics for a 2009 game, and great point-and-click gameplay. 100% Would recommend to anyone who is hesitant about it. But if it is between Trine or Trine 2, go for Trine 2. The story is pretty interesting, but you can sorta live without it.

Posted: April 28, 2014
												I bought this game for 4€ due to a steam coupon and it was totally worth it. It's a nice platforming where you can controll 3 different "heroes" with different abilities. What I really liked about this game was that you can solve the different puzzles on different ways according to your playstyle (mage,rogue or warrior) especially when you progress in the game and achieve more abilities.Although I liked this game, I thought it was way to easy. I played it the first time on "medium" and did it all on the first try (except the last level where I needed like 3 trys) and you can't really die due to the checkpoint system. Even on the difficulty "Very Hard" it was still very easy in my opinion but this might be due to my full-leveled heroes. The game has various achievements like exploring (finding all experience bottles in the levels) and "fun" achievements like jumping on 5 different skeletons; a good mix in my opinion.Finally, you can beat this game in like 7-8 hours when you play it the first time and like to explore the levels to find the experience flasks which are very nicely hidden and it's fun to explore the levels.

Posted: November 30, 2014
												Good puzzle-platformer. Trine reminds me of the old The Lost Vikings for its gameplay, you get three different characters and alternate in between them to get through the challenged on each stage.Visually very pretty, Trine's narrative has a dose of humor and a very nice soundtrack that suits well each stage. It is fun to find every hidden item on the game, and at times some clever exploration is required.The game itself is quite easy though, even on the hardest mode. Very little enemy variation (You basically kill a horde of skeletons), and it gets repetitive when you approach the end.Anyway, it was a fun ride, and certainly more than I'd ask for the price of admission.7/10

Posted: February 13, 2016
												Trine has an enchanted atmosphere, mainly bacause of the art style and the music. Bright and beautiful, it has its own way with colors and lightning, creating a calm, fairytale-like, experience. I was also impressed how magic, consisting in conjuring and telekinesis, wasn't overblown: where other games feature spellcasting machines of death, the wizard in this one is to be used with more touch and tactic. The thief is, ofcourse, athletic and fast. I have to confess that I found the warrior both uninteresting and mostly useless. The physical engine is one of the main feautures and it adds a sense of freedom and choice to the platfomring experience. The storyline, though, seemed a bit dull and cliché and I just couldn't care about it too much, even if the narrating voice had its appeal. It kind of felt like a game that takes an infantile setting and tryes to make it more mature, but doesn't succeed completely; it's also a bit too short and it won't satisfy those who are looking for more of a challenge, at least not on medium difficulty. Overally: reccomended. I will be trying the sequels as soon as possible.

Posted: October 9, 2015
												This is an absolutely brilliant game for a casual multiplayer session with a couple of friends.First of all, I'm not sure I'd play it singleplayer, as the storyline is lacklustre (something about magic and an ancient artefact, I think) and the gameplay laborious. but add another player and that's where it really shines. It plays like a platformer/puzzler hybrid and two or three players combining the different abilities of the characters makes for endless fun.Secondly, play with an Xbox controller (or similar). The keyboard/mouse controls are not so great, but it's really fluid with a controller - and this is coming from a PC gamer who has almost never used a gamepad.Essentially this game has you (and/or your friends) as a wizard (with abilities to conjour boxes etc), a knight (with a sword and magical shield) and a thief (with a grappling hook and bow). All of these abilities are well bnalanced, and you will find yourself having to use all three characters as you work around the puzzles in your way. There might be any number of solutions to a given puzzle, so it's worth trying all the characters.Finally, this game has recieved a graphical overhaul and looks absolutely beautiful. The 'theme' is a very colourful fairytale look, with locations from enchanted forests with colourful flowers, giant leaves and massive snails to underground caverns with glowing crystals and bottomless pits. It's essentially a 2.5D game (3D animation in a 2D plane), but don't let that put you off - the backgrounds and lighting are very impressive.Definitely a 9/10 - loses the one point for the weak storyline and crazy boss level, but it's still a really fun game. Definitely worth picking up.

Posted: December 5, 2015
												Wizard: uses blunt object to solve all his problems. Puzzles, walls, skeletons, you name it.Knight:  conjures the power of lightning and fire and gravity to crush his opponents to dust.Yeeaah I didn't have it the other way around.This game is friggin beautiful. THE BOXES ARE PRETTY I CARRY ALL OF THEM AS FAR IN THE LEVEL AS I CAN.no really, the visuals are 10/10. there's this one point where there's a dark place with only a singles source of light, and putting a clockwork box close to it would cast a beautifully moving shadow in the background and I just lost it. visuals 10/10the wizard: is hilarious xD he can only make boxes and that's it. but hey, if you look at the top of this review you'll know what's so fun about it. sometimes tho, you will end up gently caressing the skeleton with a box. which is really awkward. there's also the skeleton doing parkour on your boxes and he starts looking really cool. Did I mention, skeletons look hella bad♥♥♥♥♥smashing clockwork boxes you make.verdict: wizard is the best character in the game. he's pretty much the strongest if you use him right. if you don't he makes your enemies look really cool tho.knight (see top, he's awesome when he gets there)thief:grappling hook at nearly half the game constructs. that should be enough fun for you.enemies aren't too varied tho. or maybe that's just what it seems to me since theyz all skeletons.the obstacles are pretty easy xD with more than one possible solution, and each obstacle holds  a single common solution which is a stack of boxes. boxes aside, the obstacles are very diverse, and you wouldn't be bored of solving them with boxes. think onepunch man(i mean saitama is pretty bored but dude the people watching that thing sure as hell aren't).that last part was a bit anti-climatic tho :c which is sad. It sorta leaves you wanting for more, and wanting more to smash. WHICH IS NOT BAD FOR ME BECAUSE I HAVE TRINE 2 on fam share! (buying this game on sale is strongly reccomended)TLDR: the game is really amazing, yet leaves much to be desired. more enemies for example.

												Stunningly beautiful and amazingly tranquil (for a game with lots of skeletons and deadly traps), Trine is a 1-3 player puzzle-ish platformer featuring three switchable characters traversing a land full of aforementioned skeletons and deadly traps, having at their disposal a sword and a shield, a bow and a grappling hook (sic!), and the ability to conjure objects out of thin air, as well as do some telekinesis. Posted: January 2, 2016
												I played through the game single player and was left with this, "oh ok...and then?" hollow feeling.  Towards the end between items and levels it pretty much negates the difficulty and puzzles.  The narrative is pretty standard fantasy, aloof wizard, sneaky thief and meat head warrior go to the place and get the thing.PROS:+ Graphics+ Music+ Atmosphere+ It's fun+ starts off as a good puzzle platformer+ Story starts off interestingCONS:- Quit Game nag to buy Trine 3...EVERY TIME- Music can sometimes drown out diologue- Characters become too powerful for the games own good negating the puzzle aspect of the game- Faux wood...apparently in trine land there's things that look like they're made of wood but are made od marshmellows?- hit box wonkiness- anti-climaticYET I still recommend it.  Why? It's a fun game you have to look at as a small indie game from 2009 which lacked the resourcs of huge AAA studios. Yes I know it's no excuse but it helps understand it's short comings.  See for this it wasn't like a lot of games that shall remain nameless, where the short comings where not because of studio size or budget or man power but "we need something for a season pass".  BTW this is about Trine 1 not 3...just saying.Towards the end it feels like going through the motions.  In the beginning it was "shoot the rope and slam the wall like some rube goldberg machine" towards the end it's "Planks, platforms and boxes...everywhere! I have no time for you platforming puzzels".  Or "I could move the heavy box then grab it with my shield and break the wall OOOOOOr I can just thunder hammer and break everything breakable on the screen"It's like the difficulty curve doesn't match how powerful the characters get.  The last level feels like the devs knew this so they just throw things at you to throw things at you.  You die, rarely, not because of a mis jump or an attempt to solve a puzzle goes bad but because that wooden beam isn't wood, it just looks like wood OR a mob spawns where you're jumping mid jump and it's hit box is more important than yours so you Super Mario bounce into lava.It's that last level, that kinda gave me the "oh ok" feeling.   You get to the base of the tower, some lich is there for...reasons. the thief says "hurry jump on the platform".  I was expecting something like the infamous level in Ori and the Blind Forrest then a boss fight.  What I got was a "hurry as in take you time there's no rush laval moves slow after all" and nothing.This is where the short comings of the gameplay meets the short coming of the story.  The story starts off like the typical fantasy "reluctant hero(s) in the wrong place at the wrong time thrust in to this world saving adventure" even going as far as to touch on the character's motivations, yet it just ends. I was expecting a "we got the mcguffin but lets continue to work together to save the land from this lich" what I got was "This lich that coated the world in darkness and raised the dead, hit him in the face once it's his only weakness yay you win! NO QUESTIONS"I know the story isn't important, the game is mostly fun but if they're going to add a narravite then it something that will either add or take away from the game.Overall again, I do recommend it.  It's a fun game and made me want to play Trine 2. It has it's short comming and would suggest either buying 1 and 2 or getting it on sale.  It's an amazing game lumps and all for $2.25 during the 2015/6 winter sale.
